ËãπÊñπ-ÁÆÄ‰Ωì‰∏≠Êñá  my font
Hello, I seem to have a fix for this issue.
I use sqlitebrowser in a course at my university, and noticed the problem.  The cause of this issue was the Scintilla Editor output being drawn to a buffer which as it seems was not being scaled correctly. (Source: http://scintilla-interest.narkive.com/Yb4Qbh9h/scintilla-gtk-on-retina-displays)
I managed to fix the issue by setting `bufferedDraw = false` in `EditView.cpp`, in the Scintilla library.  I'm unsure if modifying the bundled library is this is within this project's constraints though.  (The modification to the app.plist file does not affect rendering or buffering within Scintilla).
In my fork, I also made some other changes to the default font size, bumped from 8 to 13 in the editor, and up to 12 in the data view.  Perhaps we could add a menu item for "High DPI mode" or some such so it's not the default for people on machines that lack high dpi support?
The before/after images are at the top of this, including the unit tests, which all passed.  I do hope this can be added, as I've seen a couple of other people reporting this issue.
https://github.com/nickberry17/sqlbrowser_with_Retina_support
Before:
<img width="1328" alt="screen shot 2016-04-25 at 5 11 32 pm" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18670565/14804675/cba472fe-0ba8-11e6-8350-3954c48d7a55.png">
After:
<img width="1328" alt="screen shot 2016-04-25 at 5 11 59 pm" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18670565/14804678/d052c274-0ba8-11e6-9868-b9ab0cf3d3db.png">
Unit Tests:
<img width="542" alt="unittests" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18670565/14804684/dacde5f8-0ba8-11e6-933d-708085cf5647.png">

);

('Billybob'),
('SuzyQ'),
('Janey');

Hi @glawrence
I would love to contribute for your community. But I don't know what to write much about, it's pretty straightforward in fact. I just hesitated to choose the build tools (qmake or cmake, gcc or MSVC...)
So my build set is : MSVC + cmake, in Microsoft Visual Studio 2013
In general you guys all setup already all .vcproj file, config & build step. All that I have to modify is the paths to dependancies (sqlcipher, Qt for MSVC 32 bits) in CMakeLists.txt file (which for now is not generic, but point to local path of your build, I think for the future you can setup some find[Package] with CMake for those dependancies).
The roughest part must be figuring out which sqlcipher .dll I have to link with, because I have differents builds from differents sources, but I choosed a C/C++ DLL for Windows pre-compiled that I order a trial from SQLCipher main site web.
Rather than make the package generic, I just modify it to make it work on my local build. I don't know if it's useful to improve your work?
> Does anyone know where to set that?
You set this in cmake-gui by selecting a 64 bit generator. All 64 bit generators for Visual Studio will have Win64 at the end.
> So, I'm unsure where it's getting x86 from. ???
The default generator is 32 bit
BTW, You can also set the generator on the command line via cmake -G "generator"
cmake --help
will list the options.

To reproduce:
Type some SELECT into the SQL and execute it (BTW, CTRL-ENTER does not work for that, only F5 -- this is another issue).
The result will show up in a grid box, but going to the cells will not update the Edit Box (even though in read-only mode just like a View)
Still does not work with the keyboard -- moving from cell to cell does not update the edit box.  It only with mouse clicks.
The CTRL-ENTER issue is OK.
(BTW, what happened to the statically built daily releases?) Well, I didn't say it should be editable.  However, the reason IMO you need the read-only edit box is because long cell contents are easier to read that way, rather than directly from the grid cell. Indeed, now ENTER is needed all the time for **both** keyboard and mouse.  (This feels awkward to me.  It's certainly worse for mouse users as they now have to use both mouse and keyboard.)
I'm not sure of the previous mouse behavior but didn't it update the edit box with each mouse click?  If so, then perhaps the mouse click event could be 'manually' called whenever the grid cell is changed by keyboard, no?  (I suppose there is some way to detect that, I don't know QT.)
Regarding multi-selection, the edit box should always show the most recently accessed grid cell contents.  Using 3.8.0, and the nightly build from 6 Jan.
When you add data via the 'browse data' table, when you press Enter to confirm data in a cell (or add new data) the 'edit database cell' window appears.  This didn't occur in 3.7.0.
If you add new data into a cell (eg, 'test') and press Enter to confirm this data, the 'edit database cell' window appears, but it is also blank.  Pressing Cancel closes the window, and the original data entered is correctly stored in the cell.
Additionally, updating the contents of a cell and pressing Enter displays the 'edit database cell' window, but this window has the original data in it.  Clicking OK on this erronous data is actually ignored - the edited data is saved.
No, 'View' -> 'Edit Cell' has the same error, but the dialog doesn't appear.  Focus is changed though...
Now if a cell contains 'test' and I overwrite it with 'test2', and press Enter, 'test2' is saved to the cell, but 'test' appears in the window underneath.  The dialog doesn't appear though.
Additionally, the 'Edit Cell' pane at the bottom is labelled 'Edit &cell'...

Thank you, please merge~  :+1:
Windows DATE is a date formatted as double, with origin at 1/1/1900. This modification allows to display doubles interpreted as a Windows DATE, similar to the unix epoch display option.
The fractional part of DATE is the hour/min/sec representation.
eg.: 42372.4709375 represents 2016-01-03 11:18:09.
I propose to add both a date and a datetime format.
date ('1899-12-30', `Date` || " days" )
would indeed be shown as
2016-01-03.
Adding to readme since that's where most people will look for this information.
If you have the edit boxed docked, and close the DB, whatever was last displayed in the Edit Box remains visible.

I have a table 'A' with Primary Key on 'ID' column. I have some data inside, however there is no record with ID = 1.
If I try to add new record in B i get:
DB Browser for SQLite
Error adding record:
CHECK constraint failed: B (INSERT INTO `B` (AID) VALUES (1, ...);)
I found out that the problem is not caused by foreign keys but constraints added to columns.
It seems that when adding new row, it is added with 'default' values and then edited with values given by user.
This is for version I downloaded today, so 3.8.0. The same applies for 3.7.0. I'm running windows, downloaded x64 version.

Corrected overlooked problem suggested by @tonypdmtr on issue [#453](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/pull/453). I make new issue because [#453](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/pull/453) is already merged.
This is a very nice feature, but I believe it can be made a bit more powerful.
1. When pasting a BLOB field, instead of getting the actual content of the blob, I simply get the string 'BLOB'.  (I don't know if this should be considered a bug or an enhancement request.)
2. An enhancement I see to this copy/paste to make it even more flexible is a one-to-many ability.
That is, if I have a single cell copied to the clipboard, but I have multiple cells selected when pasting, I would like the single value copied to each selected cell.  (It's quite common that one wants to copy a single value to a range of cells -- like in a spreadsheet.)
3. It can be made even more powerful (many-to-many) by pasting each copied cell in sequence to all selected cells.  That way, if I have copied two cells with contents 'A' and 'B', and paste to a range of five cells, I should get 'A', 'B', 'A', 'B', 'A'.  (So, the source can be more than one cell, and the destination more than one cell, but the two numbers do not need to be equal.)  This will also take care of [2] above automatically as it is a sub-case of this one.
Thanks for your great work, and Merry Christmas to all.
1. I don't thing this cannot be much better, because clipboard is in text format.
2. and 3. I'm not sure that have enough time to make that (I lack time a lot), but you could do it. Guys here are really nice and quite open for contribution.
Also consider to use SQL for such advance things. Because that I choose sqlitebrowser over spreadsheets.
Merry Christmas to you too.

When you try to open a Sqlite database which uses indexes on expressions then DB4S only shows a message box "invalid file format".
Quote from [https://www.sqlite.org/expridx.html]
> The ability to index expressions was added to SQLite with version 3.9.0 in October of 2015. A database that uses an index on expressions will not be usable by earlier versions of SQLite.
I don't think it's a bug since the SQLite team clearly states that using that new 3.9.x feature makes the database incompatible with previous versions. That's why I'm asking for an updated version.
I'm using the newest available setup for Windows (8.1), 3.7.0 which includes SQLite 3.8.10.2.
The "problem" (=incompatibility) starts after creating an index (by using another tool) which includes an expression: `create index PixelCount on Images (Width * Height)` and the database again becomes compatible after dropping such index.
```
$ sqlite3 -version
3.8.10.2 2015-05-20 18:17:19 2ef4f3a5b1d1d0c4338f8243d40a2452cc1f7fe4
```
```
Version 3.7.0
Qt Version 4.8.7
SQLCipher Version 3.8.6
```
on OS X 10.11.2

In table view I added a filter for a column. The column contains a text representation of a date as yyyy-mm-dd (e. g. 2013-04-27).
**Example 1**
Filter `>2010`
SQL-Log: `SELECT rowid,* FROM msgs_view WHERE 1=1 AND date > 2010 ORDER BY date DESC LIMIT 0, 50000;`
Problem: It's a text field but filtering is done numeric.
**Example 2**
Filter `>2010-10-01`
SQL-Log: `SELECT rowid,* FROM msgs_view WHERE 1=1 AND date LIKE '>2010-10-01' ORDER BY date DESC LIMIT 0, 50000;`
Problem: It's executed as LIKE filter and not as GREATER THAN
**Remark**
There is always an additional sql execution to detect the number of rows
`SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (SELECT rowid,* FROM msgs_view WHERE 1=1 AND date LIKE '>2010-10-01' ORDER BY date DESC);`
Shouldnt ORDERY BY be omitted for performance reasons?
This isn't an issue with sqlitebrowser -- I didn't know the appropriate way to reach you.
When I look at the OSX .app Frameworks folder of sqlitebrowser, I noticed that your project is much smaller than my Qt app -- you utilize less Qt framework bundles. How did you get your application to support that? For instance, I'm not using QtQuick or QML in my Qt/C++ application. However, when I run my project through macdeployqt, it includes these frameworks in my app bundle. When I try to remove them, my application won't load.
I found what's going on in my Qt/C++ app. Once I included QtWebKit, it
increased the size by several MB and forced the adding of QtQML and
QtQuick, even though I'm not using those. If I don't add that, the other
frameworks don't get deployed by macdeployqt.

I suggest you try searching the internet for "Exception code: 0xc0000005" which returns all sorts of possible causes from bad memory to corrupt video drivers, if you add in "ntdll.dll" then you might find something more specific or helpful. However I am sorry to say this suggests the problem is with your computer and not DB Browser for SQLite. See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1282792 :
"In the browse data tab, add new row, then double click a field. The popup window appeared to edit the field, and it froze."
Problem is that during synchronization of the plaintextedit and hexedit, the updated editor emits the changed signal which then triggers another syncronization, and so on, resulting in a stack overflow due to infinite recursion:
```
[...]

I had this problem, but I think it was because Chrome had the file open while sqlitebrowser was trying to read it. I made a copy of the file, and sqlitebrowser was able to open it.  Picking up on #184
- SQLite 3 seems to use affinity types - ( https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#affinity ) - and has baked in support for column types such as 'DATETIME' etc.
In SQLite Browser, if I execute the SQL that creates a columntype of DATETIME, SQLite supports it, and DATETIME is shown for the column type.
However, when trying to add / edit a column type, these types are not supported, even if I type them in manually.
Perhaps the default column types could be listed, but the add / edit dropdown will accept custom types as well.
I feel this qualifies as a bug - as I can't use your tool to access a built-in function of SQLite.

I just worked through getting it to build on Qt 4.6.2, on a locked down Linux machine.
It struggled with a few errors when building v3.5.1.
Here are the errors:
```
main.cpp: In function 'int main(int, char**)':

EditTableDialog.cpp:20: error: 'currentMSecsSinceEpoch' is not a member of 'QDateTime'

FilterTableHeader.cpp:14: error: 'setPlaceholderText' was not declared in this scope
```
I'll see about doing a pull request sometime with the fixes.
Fixes basically were:
Add `#include <QFile>` to main.cpp
Wrap includes for `QElaspedTimer` with:
```
#if (QT_VERSION < QT_VERSION_CHECK(4, 7, 0))
# include <QTime>
typedef QTime QElapsedTimer;
#else
# include <QElapsedTimer>
#endif
```
Wrap calls to `QDateTime::currentMSecsToEpoch()` with
```
#if QT_VERSION < QT_VERSION_CHECK(4, 7, 0)
QDateTime::currentDateTime().toTime_t() * 1000
#else
QDateTime::currentMSecsSinceEpoch()
#endif
```
Wrap call to `QLineEdit::setPlaceHolderText()` with
```
#if (QT_VERSION < QT_VERSION_CHECK(4, 7, 0))
// setPlaceHolderText(tr("Filter"));
#else
setPlaceHolderText(tr("Filter"));
#endif
```
Hope that helps someone.  These fixes should make it backwards compatible with Qt 4.6.
I'll try rebuilding it with 4.6 on a home computer this weekend. I found
those errors on a locked down computer without internet access.  Sorry
about the late response.  Does it still build easily with 4.8 since
supporting qt 5?
This is an old thread, but I'll just add that yesterday it saved my hide.  Qt-4.6 may be ancient, but it's what's in use in RedHat 6.8, which is still widely used in industry.  This patch is not irrelevant to me.  Just for jollies, and to be informative, my company-standard installation has qt-1:4.6.2-28 and qt3-3.3.8b-30 installed.  (If you thought Qt-4.6 was old...)  I have qt5-5.6.1-3 available but not installed - apparently nothing "standard" has called for it.  The preparations are beginning to upgrade to RedHat 6.9, but I'm not sure what Qt code levels that will entail or when it will happen. Awesome!  Glad it was useful.  The biggest thing to watch for with older versions of RedHat is support for OpenGL or the MesaGL libraries and xcb support.  If those are fully installed and supported, then Qt 5 will play nice.  Otherwise some gotchas come up.  Qt 4.8.x doesn't need OpenGL, and Qt Lite (in Qt 5.8+) also doesn't need OpenGL.    I have a question regarding the built-in plotting function. I observed that for larger databases (~ 2M entries) the plots look quite different compared to plots made with e.g. python. I also observed that the plots very much depend on the ordering of the entries in the database.
Since the plots are extremely fast, I assume that you perform some kind of "thinning" before doing the plot? I am right about this? Could you elaborate about the details of how the plots are done?
Thanks,
Christoph Niehoff
The plots depend on what x and y axis(columns) you select,
and of course how your current select statement looks like.
And no there shouldn't be any data left out for plotting, all data that is returned from the select should be used to plot
Dear Rene,
thank you for you reply!
Let me give you an example.
When I perform the two following select's:
1) select dataA, dataB from DataBase order by dataA
2) select dataA, dataB from DataBase order by dataB
I assume that in both cases I have the same datapoints (or am I wrong here? I am quite new to SQL... ).
But when I make plots with dataA on the x-axis and dataB on the y-axis, I get totally different outcomes  for both cases (different distributions of datapoints and different plot ranges).
Also, I can make a plot with all points. Then I can perform a select that only returns entries, which are in a region, where the plot with all points didn't have any points. This select then shows that there are entries in the database, that the plot did not show...
I assume that this very much depends on the structure of my data. My database contains ~2M entries generated by ~500 different Markov Chains, so the data is pretty much "clustered"...
Thanks very much,
Christoph
I had a look at the code(some time has past since I wrote it) and I think I have not really accounted such order by statements and the plotting is still more or less some kind of prototype. So this is more or less a bug or missing functionality.
But I can say that we pass all the data returned from the statement to the plotting widget (qcustomplot), but as you noticed it may happen that some data is not shown, thats because it's not possible to draw every datapoint if the x-axis is too large and the plotting widget has to skip data.
Dear Rene,
thank you very much for taking the time to look into the code.  I think, this pretty much explains it. Thanks, that helped a lot.
All the best,
Christoph

open base
amend data

press (ESC) (2 times why?)
when you try to make a change in the base will be informed that it is locked
all right

That's great news. Do you know what you had before exactly? Just in case there is an issue.
With monospace fonts query editor rendering seems to be ignoring the proper space width. Screenshots below are both of the exact same text using 10pt Courier New with the red line 1px after the select keyword.
How it should look: Notepad++ 6.7.9
![notepad _6 7 9](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12277525/10455659/f57223a2-7192-11e5-80ed-f36572dcbca8.png)
How it looks: DBBrowser 3.7.0
![dbbrowser_3 7 0](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12277525/10455658/f5519a1a-7192-11e5-9b12-7a376d017c46.png)
Please note that spaces might not be the only characters involved and **_formatting_** might also affect the result.
Here is the text:
```
select sum(ValorNeto) as Neto, sum(ValorIVA + ValorNeto) as Total
from NV
on NV.IdEntidad = Entidad.IdEntidad
on NV.IdNVEstado = NVEstado.IdNVEstado
{1};
```

Thanks! I'm closing the ticket now as the issue has been resolved. Don't know if it's worth mentioning that the **output** font remains uniformly small...but maybe that's intended? Or in an option that I've missed (is it not the SQL Log Font Size, which I've set to be 32 in the screenshot above, the same as in the SQL Editor Font Size setting)?
If I have one more interface suggestion to make, based on my experience in using SQLite Browser for live demos and teaching SQL in-class, it's that that bottom output panel can be very easy to miss, even for me, but especially for new users/SQL novices who don't realize that it's related to the execution of the query...which gets confusing for novices who struggle with knowing the difference between an empty query set and an actual error. Configuring the font-size would be helpful, but even a little color flash upon update, or a red-highlight border around the output box in the event of an error, would be really helpful.
Thanks again!

https://github.com/Simsys/qhexedit2
yes we use qhexedit, it was introduced while @MKleusberg reworked the value editor dialog a long time ago.

Hello Martin,
I understand your concerns. Perhaps just as information: SQLite Studio shows up an interrupt button when a query is engaged, works fine, so far no problems, but not heavily used anyway.
I came to this, because by un(for)seen changes at my collected measurement data I run into troubles with my (old) queries: SQLite Studio could interrupt them, SQLite Browser I had to kill each time ...
Personally I much more like SQLite Browser; I use SQLite Studio for some work because here I can attach a bunch of databases by a set of query statements, which SQLite Browser cannot.
Regards

I thought there was going to be something under Preferences that specifically addressed row height. Changing the browser font size will change the row height indirectly but I saw nothing that would change the row height directly. For example, a smaller row height with no change in font size would reduce the white space between each line.
One minor change I noticed. File names in the new version use forward slashes / instead of back slashes \ . It just looks unusual to see some of the files with back slashes and some with forward slashes when I view the most recent files in the Files menu. I think the Windows default is back slashes, although I believe either will work. As a PC user, this is something I've never paid much attention to.

I tried to delete the content of a table "myTable" in an attached database "myDB":
DELETE FROM myDB.myTable;
And got the following error:
no such table: myDB.Tablename: DELETE FROM myDB.myTable
(Where "Tablename" is the name of a table in the main database)
The table itself exists, so a query on that table works:
SELECT \* FROM myDB.myTable;
Deletion on the main database works fine also:
DELETE FROM main.myTable;

When a field contains line feeds, in the Browse Data tab, the contents are displayed on the same line but without any space between the lines.  I propose you replace line feeds with a space so as to look better as single line.  For example:
If fields contains:
Hello<CRLF>
World
It now displays as:
HelloWorld
(no space between Hello and World)
After my suggestion:
Hello World
That would work also (even better, actually).  However, still a space should surround the special character or else again it will look as one word when printed as a single line.
I would like an option for Filter to automatically enclose whatever typed text in %% so as to not to have to type the % all the time.  This is because I have found that practically always I need a ‚Äú%text%‚Äù type search instead of just ‚Äútext‚Äù.
That's why I thought of it as a settable option (View/Preferences)
Better yet, a checkbox right next to the filters row where one can immediately change the default, and also verify its current state.
Hi,
another problematic point here is the immediate activation of the filter while still typing. With big data it took relevant time to complete the intendet filter phrase, and the program does filtering again and again with every of the next typed in characters.
1) drop this auto activation behaviour (not that conveniant)
2) make it optional by Setting (a bit better)
3) define a certain amount of time to wait that no further Input is done in the filter field and only then start filter Action (my best bet, i.e. 400ms might be a good starting point)
Regards
This seems unrelated to this proposal as the only difference is that the LIKE argument will be automatically embraced by % characters.  None of the remaining functionality is affected.
As for appropriate solutions to the other issue, I'd go with 3.
I appreciate all the work put into this, and the result is very good.
If I'm looking for John, typing John will give me both and there may be cases where I only need to see just John without Johnson.  And, there is no way to make it not find Johnson.
I think some kind of on/off switch for this option is needed.
(BTW, one minor note about the implementation.  I looked at the code and when the string is empty it is replaced by '%%' when just one '%' is sufficient.  Not important in that it does not change the behavior.)
I didn't know about the = option.  That will work just as well. Thanks.
It's OK as far as I'm concerned!
Hi,
Thanks for a great product.
My Name is Svein Berger (mr.) I'm a Norwegian software developer.
First I want to apologize for my limited knowledge of English. So please try to understand my note.
We are using an technical application that saves data to a SQLite database.
The first version of the program was written in Delphi. Later I rewrote the program in C#.
The character set back then was Windows western europe (same as CP1252)
When I rewrote the program to C# i kept the old character set. That was because it was to complicated to convert the data to UTF-8.
As a Norwegian (it applies to most countries in Europe), we use letters that are outside A..Z like √∏√¶√• √∂ √º etc.
At the time we startet to use our database UTF-8 was not the common character sets. The transition to UTF-8 is no problem for those who only use the letters A..Z. But for us who live in countries that have an extended alphabet, the transition to UTF-8 is a challenge for some older systems. The letters A..Z kept the same places in the new character set, but the letters that we use was "shuffled around".
An example: Pressure test is in Norwegian Trykkpr√∏ving. But it is like this TrykkprÔøΩving in DB Browser for SQLite. For all charaters √ò√Ü√Ö √∏√¶√• is displayed like ÔøΩ. Not very nice.
Pleas see attatched screen shot.
If I had written the program to day, I would of course used UFT-8, and everyone would be happy.
I fully understand that you do not add an additional interpretations of the character set in the program. But if you have the opportunity and see this as a challenge, I would be more than happy to test the solution for you.
If I make my self unclear, please ask me and I will try my best to answer you.
Kind regards
Svein Berger
IT Manager
sveinb@ttc.no

There was a previous problem (https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/394) in the Window's version that was fixed on August 19th 2015. Later it got broken, which I mentioned in that thread, but here's a new report with up-to-date information. :smiley:
Now, the Edit-window is alternating between two places depending on the position of the main form. First it appears in one place, then the other next time it's opened. If the main window is moved, it's two different places. Sometimes half way outside the screen border.
The position of the main form is stored when the application is closed, so wouldn't it be a good idea if you added a setting in Preferences to also store the position of the Edit-window? Those who don't have any problems can leave that setting unchecked and will have the applications default behaviour. :smile:

Try to go exactly according to instructions...
I installed SqliteBrowser recently, and to my surprise found that the program tries to make a https connection to an IP automatically at launch. With the amount of open-source involvement in this, I realize this probably something innocuous like Checking for updates or something, but even then, connecting to some IP without any form of notification to the user raises immediate red flags to me.
If it is indeed about automatic updates, please allow the user to choose it consciously, rather than doing it behind the curtains. With a simple dialogue at first launch, saying "Automatic updates are enabled and will ensure DB4S is at the latest version" - with a prominent OK button and a "Change setting" text link that takes you to the Preferences page - you can also ensure that only those who really wish to disable auto-updates do that. Currently, even if the user wishes not to allow external connections (for whatever reason), a connection is going to happen at the very first launch, before (s)he has a chance to change the Preferences.
And whenever update check is going on, you could also give a simple notification, putting to use the several unused pixels at the bottom of the window. I consider this necessary because, given that DB4S is a desktop program that one doesn't expect to connect to the Internet, making external connections is an unusual state for the program and something that deserves a user notification. Putting it at the bottom left also keeps it similar to browser status messages, which would make it easier for users to grok.
I found it support 2d chart on GUI. Does it support 3d plt based on X, Y, Z data?

... and how to use them?
Of course ^^ Thanks for your help @justinclift @MKleusberg :+1:
UTF16 = Case sensitive compare
UTF16CI = Case insensitive compare
comparison is performed by QString functions.
AFAIK the Byte order of QStrings are CPU dependent. This means, that the collation does not work if the byte order of QString does not match the byte order of the database.
The reason to choose this collating sequence was the need for a Unicode collation that really matched the in-memory comparison. Especially regarding  non-UCS2 chars and Unicode normalization. The performance should be OK as we're not copying any data here.
to repeat:
1) create table,with some column
2) click "correct table"
3) add some column
4) move any column

```
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version = 20150623;
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version;
20150623
```
However, when viewing the database from DB4S, the User_Version will not be displayed correctly (it will be 10000) if the value is higher than 10000.
According to SQLite3 (https://www.sqlite.org/pragma.html#pragma_schema_version) the user_version is a 32-bit signed integer (maximum value is 2,147,483,647).
```
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version = 2147483647;
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version;
2147483647
```
Thanks for the quick reply and fix. I will test it tomorrow and get back to you.
Yes, it is working. The User_Version is displayed correctly now. Thanks a lot.
Function `setFont()`, without params, sets font for all lexems types. .
To set default font color to black I used `sqlLexer->setColor(Qt::black, QsciLexerSQL::Default)`.
That's also keeps numbers color with aquablue color
And it doesn't  looks very clever now, it thinks that every not special english SQL word is table or column name.
![workspace 1_065](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5500999/8290579/2dca5b18-194e-11e5-93aa-478376843c6e.png)
There is some old bug which presented from version 3.6. Look at this picture (first line) that's how it looks now, cyrillic characters (out of comments and quotes) are drawn with different font:
![image 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5500999/8280145/0e3f9ea2-190d-11e5-84ce-87f600c57cda.png)
That's how it was in version 3.5.1 and probably the way it should be:
![image 6](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5500999/8280115/c6f13772-190c-11e5-8a12-39bb50c75e8c.png)
There is the test string:
``` SQL
–∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—è
-- –∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—è
SELECT *
FROM Student
WHERE name like '–ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä%'
```
This problem is presented also on windows and linux. Also changing font size doesn't affect size of this characters. Looks like It's also affect arithmetic characters and digits:
``` SQL
-- –∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—è
SELECT 1234567890-=/+,.\|
FROM Student
WHERE name like '–ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä%'
```

...
textEdit->setUtf8(true);

textEdit->setLexer(lex);
...
```

![untitled txt- - application_061](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5500999/8285861/610da598-1930-11e5-991d-00bb2a480cbe.png)

I found out that if make this small fix in SqlTextEdit::reloadSettings() function, everything starts to work, but I'm not sure will it broke something or not...
``` cpp
...
defaultfont.setPointSize(PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue("editor", "fontsize").toInt());
// sqlLexer->setDefaultFont(defaultfont); // comment this line
sqlLexer->setFont(defaultfont); // and replace with this line
setupSyntaxHighlightingFormat("comment", QsciLexerSQL::Comment);
...
```
Ok, let me try =)
I tried to delete a column via the "Modify Table" popup. Selecting the column and clicking on "Remove" brought up a popup that said "No error", but the column remained. The SQL log for the app shows:
SAVEPOINT sqlitebrowser_rename_column
CREATE TABLE `sqlitebrowser_rena... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
INSERT INTO sqlitebrowser_rename_column_new_table SELECT`_ID`,`name`,`local_path_template`,`is_localized`,`is_automatic`,`file_set_id`FROM`FileInfo`;
DROP TABLE`FileInfo`;
ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT sqlitebrowser_rename_column;
which I interpret to mean that a) the rollback means that the operation failed, despite the "No error" popup, and b) perhaps binary data in the CREATE TABLE statement is not helping, either? (Could this be a side-effect of the new UTF-8 support?)
Thanks for asking. I'm making an assumption here (yes, I could try it out, but... :-) that the sqlite API reports an error message if you try to delete a table, or rows in a table, that can't be deleted due to a FK constraint. So if sqlite's error message(s) could be displayed in the popup, instead of it displaying "No error", that would be a big help. If that's not feasible, then even "Unknown Error" would be better. As it was, the "No error" lulled me into thinking that indeed no error had occurred. (Maybe "No error" was displayed not to mean that no error had occurred, but rather that an error _had_ occurred but the browser couldn't determine what the error was.)
I realize this is asking quite a bit more, but: It would be great if, when I try to delete a table or column that's referenced by a foreign key, the browser could tell me in advance of execution "You can't do that; it's got foreign keys pointing to it."

I've used the SQLCipher instructions to allow my iOS app to create an encrypted database.  When I try to open it in sqlitebrowser I just continuously get prompted to enter the password.  I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong.  Any ideas?
It does use SQLCipher to do the encryption, what i don't know is what the page size is.  I wrote the app using the instructions on the SQLCipher website, but it doesn't say anything about what page size it's using.  What can I do to start investigating?
Thanks for your help, I found the problem.  You mentioned building sqlitebrowser with a newer version of SQLCipher, well that's what I needed to do.  My iOS app was using an old version of SQLCipher.  Once I updated SQLCipher to the latest from github, I could read my databases in sqlitebrowser.  I even tested with sqlitebrowser 3.7.0 and it worked great.  Thanks for your help!

I‚Äôm using a Cinnamon shell over GNOME (v.v. GTK3+ based), so yes there could be a source of divergence.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30643061/sqlite-db-browser-invalid-operand-for-regexp
I use DB Browser for SQLite version 3.6.0; SQLite Version 3.8.9. If I use regexp on a nullable column `revision` then `invalid operand` error is happened.
``` sql
SELECT brand,revision FROM TDevice WHERE TDevice.revision regexp '^ASUS$';
```
Below is the schema:
``` sql
CREATE TABLE `TDevice` (
`id`    INTEGER NOT NULL,
`model` varchar(128) NOT NULL,
`revision`  TEXT,
PRIMARY KEY(id)
);
```
After I replaced the NULL `revision` with empty string, then this issue fixed.
``` sql
UPDATE TDevice SET revision='' WHERE revision IS NULL
```
I assume `regexp` should behave as `LIKE` operator, because `LIKE` operator can accept NULL text.
When a table is empty an you export, (suing the first 2 checkbox)
it will export an additional ); just after the create table.
Consequently, It makes an error  when you import,
It works with the latest nightly build.
Thanks !!!!
Using File > Export > Database to SQL File:
Tables containing some data, are written correctly. But for empty tables, an extra ); is added on a new line, after the table.
Example:
correct:
CREATE TABLE "Table_with_data" (
"object_id" INTEGER NOT NULL,
"value" REAL NULL);
INSERT INTO `Table_with_data` VALUES (1,40.0);
INSERT INTO `Table_with_data` VALUES (2,90.0);
CREATE TABLE "Empty_table" (
"object_id" INTEGER NOT NULL,
"value" REAL NULL);
); <<<<<<<<<< redundant closing bracket
OK, I will. I'll let you know if it works. Thanks for fixing!
Hi Justin,
Just tested with the nightly build and confirm fixed. Export is correct.
Thanks,

version: 3.6.0
while execute sql,
the sentence :
select \* from refer where namecn like '%ÊúØËØ≠%'
will be looks like this:
select \* from refer where namecn like '%??%'

Since sqlitebrowser is oriented towards end-users, it would be optimal if it could be executed from the command line to open a specific database, switch to a specific tab (e.g. Browse Data), open a specific table, and (if feasible) do so either "read-only" or "editing enabled".
Example:
"C:\Program Files (x86)\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe  --path=x:\mydb.db   --tab=browse   --table=mytable   --action=edit  "
This capability would enable sqlitebrowser to be executed from other applications within a specific context for a specific purpose while ensuring that the end-user gets exactly where they need to be.

When you enter a query in "Execute SQL" tab with line-break, your query is not logged properly :
The first line is logged then
&lt;string can not be logged, contains binary data&gt;
Maybe replacing line-breaks with whitespaces could solve the issue.
DB4S 3.6.0 under Windows 8.1 pro x64
Just checked 3.7.0, not solved.
a query which don't need a working database :
```
WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt;
```
taken from [Recursive Query Examples](https://www.sqlite.org/lang_with.html)
Every line is logged correctly, no longer truncated and no
&lt;string can not be logged, contains binary data&gt;
but...
a side effect appeared: empty lines are logged in User log
if you add 5 empty lines at the end of you sql command, User log will contains 5 empty lines
this is not the case in Application log
this issue is not present in 3.7.0 release
I notice the Application log is sightly different than User log
Just to be sure I explained the behavior clearly:
Consider this 4 lines query (3 lines + 1 empty)
```
WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt;
```
With v3.7.0 this query creates 2 lines in User log:
```
WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VAL... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
```
and 3 lines in Application log:
```
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (WITH RECUR... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VAL... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
```
With nightly build, the 4 lines of the query are copy/paste in User log:
```
WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt;
```
And 6 lines in Application log:
```
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt);
WITH RECURSIVE
cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt LIMIT 0, 50000;
```
I would really like to help improve DB4S but I'm unable to build the source code actually.
I checked the latest nightly,
the commit from @MKleusberg is working perfectly.

The new 64-bit version is obviously not an update but a completely separate program to any existing 32-bit installation. Certainly not a bug by any means, but perhaps a note could be included somewhere for unaware users.
I was unaware of sqlitebrowser's 32-bit-only history and just assumed it had always come in 64-bit offerings when I saw the 64-bit download. As a result, my head got scratched a few times when it kept asking me to install 3.60 even after updating. It only dawned on me when I uninstalled 3.60 and still saw 3.40 sitting in my x86 folder :)
Well, I can think of at least two ideas.
The most useful spot would be in the 'There is a new version, please download' pop-up alert that appears, since it's what triggers most users to download the new version in the first place. Having such a note would clutter up the alert window though, and wouldn't be relevant to someone updating to a 32-bit version or (eventually) from a 64-bit version.
The neater solution is to have the installer detect existing 32-bit installations as well and uninstall them before continuing. This turns into a much bigger implementation though, with the need to migrate user configs/etc to the new directory in addition to the 32-bit detection.
Not a critical issue now but maybe something to think of down the line? I'm sure this happens in countless other projects too- maybe others have addressed the issue elegantly before.
Can do! Need to work on some projects at the moment but will be sure to
find some time this weekend for you. Great to hear about your progress :)

I'm not sure about that. What will happen if you choose "No"? From a purely UI pov a warning with just one button has the same effect: you execute the query anyway. So what the user (me) needs to know is what effect will the choices have.
Something like:
Title: "NOCASE collation does not handle multi-byte characters. Proceed? "
Message:
"A table in this database requires a special collation function '%1' "
"that this application can't provide without further knowledge.\n"
"If you do proceed, YYY.\n"
"Be aware bad things can happen to your database. Create a backup!"
Replace the YYY and NNN with the effects.

Previous versions were all build statically. So I could have exe file in one directory.. The 3.6.0 is build dynamically with a bunch of files which is not very nice. You should also link to the msvcrt statically.
As the title says I'm having trouble registering the `*.db` file extension. When I double click such a file I'm asked to select the program to open it with. When I navigate to `C:\Program Files\sqlitebrowser3\bin` and choose `sqlitebrowser.exe` it is not added to the "Open with" window and thus I can't select it as the default option.
It seems like the same issue, but I didn't find it using the search. I'll attempt the solution later this week and let you know.
Yes that solution has worked for me. I changed the value of `HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlitebrowser.exe\shell\open\command` from `"C:\Program Files (x86)\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe" "%1"` to `"C:\Program Files\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe" "%1"` and the extension can once again be registered. Thanks for the help.

Hi guys,
I've got tables with fields marked as NotNull. Tried to add a new record which returns "Error adding record: NOT NULL constraint failed".
I'm guessing the logic defaults everything to NULL for the user to change.
Current workaround: uncheck not null fields, add new record, populate with requisite data, recheck not null fields

In the 'structure' as well as the 'DB Schema' (aren't those two not the same ref to the table called 'sqlite_master' and therefore can better carry only one of aforementioned names [my suggestion 'Schema', bc it's called like that in most books and RFC's] ?) window is a column 'type' (may be one of the four on the left - 'table', 'view', 'index', 'trigger' [ eventually 'meta', but in practice I've never seen such a type... ] so to save space and avoid confusion to others and me you may safely remove it. I see. I missed such a case.
At any case, `using QAbstractTableModel::setData` is a bad solution.
`setData` mehod I modified should be implemented as another method (not as overload), I guess.
The another method is like following.
``` cpp
bool setTypedData(const QModelIndex& index, bool isBlob, const QVariant& value, int role);
// or
bool setTypedData(const QModelIndex& index, int dataType, const QVariant& value, int role);
```

With large CREATE TABLE statements, the interface kinda messes up in those two interfaces (Database Structure tab, and the right side window, DB Schema), as it tries to show the full CREATE TABLE statement with all the newlines, tabs and spaces included. These CREATE TABLE statements are created by SQLAlchemy, so thats why they are formatted that way, but it theoretically could happen with manual written statements too if people like them to look pretty in the code.
Easier to show a screenshot: http://i.imgur.com/8bCmexZ.png
I would suggest making it so that the Database Structure tab, all the 'tables' are not so far apart (as it shows the large Create Table statement by default, and maybe have that as a drop down arrow as a child of the table, so it doesn't mess up the formatting/spacing of the table by default?
And also for the DB Schema side window on the right, i dont think there is a need to show the full CREATE TABLE statement anyway, as you are already parsing out the individual columns anyway and showing the relevant part (per the column) right next to the column anyway. Maybe add entries for Foreign Keys and you won't need the whole CREATE TABLE statement?
That option does exist! thanks.
I guess i just don't understand why we even have the 'text' schema there at all, what does 'column_name VARCHAR(200)' tell us that already parsed columns with the 'name' and 'type' information in the respective columns don't? I would support just getting rid of the text schema (except for maybe one place), and just have everything be available in the graphical tree view, including foreign keys, NOT NULL constraints, etc
Another picture, this of MySQLWorkbench, a program that is basically like sqlitebrowser only for mysql, and it sorta has what i'm envisioning for the schema views, where everything is available in a tree like fashion and we don't really need the giant CREATE TABLE string...
http://i.imgur.com/KGfYq4m.png

Had the same issue for the 64 bit version. I figured that the registry entry is still pointing to the wrong directory. So in HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlitebrowser3.exe\shell\open\command the value needs to be changed from "C:\Program Files (x86)..." to  "C:\Program Files..."
If I remove HKCR\Applications\sqlitebrowser.exe and then associate with "c:\Program Files\sqlitebrowser3\bin\sqlitebroswer.exe" windows keeps the association. But if there is an exisiting shell\open\command (with an incorrect path) for the application it does not.
Maybe the installer made by cmake nsis generator works in a similar way. Without an explicit removal of that key it just leaves the exisiting?

Well its _very_ basic but here's a start. I didn't know how to do a pull request on a wiki so https://github.com/maxslimmer/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Windows-File-Associations
Having first edited @maxslimmer copy of the Wiki I have now coped this to the sqlitebrowser wiki and added the link.
@justinclift let me know if we need anything else doing but I think we can close this issue now like #296
I have seen other software do one of two things:
- put a check box in the installer, so users can opt in to file association if they want
- options in the preferences for file association
Pretty sure this is possible either way, another option is both. However I think we need to support multiple and possibly custom file extensions given sqlite files don't have a standard extension
I guess we need a good wiki page and a Tweet? Or something like that anyway. Maybe http://sqlitebrowser.org/ should link direct to the wiki, as well as GitHub, some people might not know there is documentation in the form of the wiki on the GitHub site.
Thanks, an option in the installer sounds excellent.  This would also help the users who had created associations by hand that subsequently got broken with renaming.
You will need to decide what extensions to use.  As a starting point for that, according to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/808499/what-is-the-best-extension-name-sqlite-database-files
> Emacs expects one of db, sqlite, sqlite2 or sqlite3 in the default configuration for sql-sqlite mode
A user preference in the program would be convenient.  However it needs to be done carefully because changing file associated settings needs temporary escalation to Administrator access.
I feel that the developers should choose either install time or a subsequent preference depending on implementation factors.  As a user, I would welcome and can adapt to either.
Excellent.  One other thought - if possible please can the installer allow a reconfigure option to change the setting of any config options without forcing a reinstall.  Often when I am evaluating software, I don't want to take over existing extensions.  But then when I decide to use it to replace my existing software, I want to go back and enable the extensions.

You guys work fast ^_^
Running Windows 7, 64-bit OS.
I had a 32-bit version of 3.5.1. This time around I decided to go 64-bit for 3.6.0v2. I uninstalled the 32-bit version (which wasn't registered in Windows 7's Add/Remove Programs list, so I had to find it and use uninstall.exe), but unfortunately it didn't get everything.
I installed 64-bit, and double clicked on a .db file. It brought up the 32-bit version that I thought I had just uninstalled. I did this a couple times and then uninstalled 64-bit, searched my hard drive manually deleting every sqlitebrowser.exe I could find.  I re-installed 64-bit, but now I could not double click on my .db files and make them open in sqlite browser. It associated with the next program on the list (just happened to be 7zip, and 7zip choked...).
In any case, digging into the registry, I found that the key HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlitebrowser.exe\shell\open\command\Default was still set to  "C:\Program Files **(x86)**\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe" "%1". This confused Windows 7 and would not let it associate the new, 64-bit install with .db. Once I whacked that and re-installed 64-bit, it was shiny.
tl;dr: Make sure that the uninstall whacks that reg key so an install with a different target (32/64/ia/etc) will not confuse Windows.
Other than that, great job with 3.6.0v2. I like it. :-)
Ah. That's why it didn't unset them. :-)
My bad.

Perhaps a feature rather than a bug.
I used an open-source conversion program to go from an SQL file to a SQLlite file.  That program left the data types in the table schema in their original SQL form.  One was a "bit" type.  Your browser seems to interpret that reasonably.  It displays as either 0 or 1.  When I run an sql command in your browser to select for 0 or 1, it works as expected.
But when I run the same command in SQLlite3, it never selects regardless of the bit value.
It appears that the browser is interpreting data types in a different way than SQLlite3.  So while the browser's liberal behavior is a nice convenience, it is misleading.  Perhaps the browser should display the type being used?  Or warn?
Otherwise, I'm very happy with it in my rather limited experience to date.

I am having the same problem. I have tried the same directory approach , and no dice..
Win7 x64    db version  3.8.0
I ran into this same issue and I finally got it to work. It has to do with the library search paths on Windows because `mod_spatialite` in turn loads its own dependent DLLs that reside in the same directory as `mod_spatialite.dll`.
I got it working 2 different ways:
1.) Add the directory containing the spatialite `.dll` files to your `%PATH%`. Windows searches `%PATH%` for dll files so it will be able to locate it.
2.) Copy the `.dll` files to the same directory containing `DB Browser for SQLite.exe`. e.g. `C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite` or `C:\Program Files (x86)\DB Browser for SQLite` whichever version you have installed (32bit or 64bit). You will also want to make sure you use the correct x86 or x64 dll files that correspond to the version of sqlitebrowser you have.
This works because Windows searches for .dll files in `%PATH%` and the current application directory. So putting them in either place works.
If `mod_spatialite` were shipped as fat binary containing _everything_ in a single dll file I don't believe this would be necessary and it would just work pointing it at the dll, but until then we have to make sure all of the .dll's are located somewhere Windows will search when loading shared libs. I added a new page.

To perhaps clarify a bit more outside of the twitter character limit!  We have a SQLite DB in our Unity project, and a requirement was encryption.  sqlcipher wasn't supported by the SQLite Unity plugin we used (https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/4334), so we had to use their "PRAGMA key = X" to encrypt the DB on devices.  We would love a way to then use sqlitebrowser to decrypt the contents of this DB after pulling it off a device and entering our key.  I grabbed the latest nightly build of sqlitebrowser as well as the cipher-enabled version, but neither of them will decrypt our DB. (though i'm unsure if changing the "page size" value in sqlcipher version would help, I have no idea what value I'd use there)
The format of key we're using is:  0x5c516e4e21a65b8fee841db84b462367
(some digits changed to protect the innocent, but length remains the same as what we're using)

@justinclift Has been made any progress on this?   This is occurring in the latest nightly Windows build.
When modifying the order of fields, the 'move up/down' buttons are disabled when at the top/bottom of the list. But if you click on another row, then hold down the mouse button and drag to one of the end rows, the movement buttons are not properly disabled. So you can click to move the top row up and the bottom row down, both of which crash the application.
The inverse also works, so if you click the bottom row, then drag up one row, the "move down" button will be disabled even though you should be able to move the field. So basically it seems like the listener for disabling those buttons triggers on the mouse click, not the actual final selection after dragging around.

On Wed, Apr 15, 2015 at 12:32 PM, Justin Clift notifications@github.com

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:

Okay. I figured out how to do this. Create an Automator service that runs a shell script. I even included a notification center to prompt with the filename as it opens. But that's not necessary.
```
for f in "$@"
do
osascript -e "display notification \"$f\" with title \"Opening file:\""
open -a "sqlitebrowser" "$1"
done
```
![screen shot 2015-04-16 at 10 42 42 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6953274/7184905/5d941edc-e425-11e4-8fec-9f246c4e3f71.png)

It would be convenient of pressing 'tab' in the SQL editor when multiple lines of text were selected indented all of the lines. The current behavior replaces the selection with a tab.
EXPLAIN QUERY PLAN SELECT BlahField FROM BladDb WHERE foo=0;
begins a transaction when one is not required.
When using the DB browser to execute certain queries it enables the "write changes" and "revert changes" options when this is not required. This means DB Browser creates a transaction that is awaiting a COMMIT or ROLLBACK but no such thing is required in this case since the explain verb does not write anything. In journal DELETE mode an empty journal is created.
SELECT BlahField FROM BladDb WHERE foo=0;
works as expected and no transaction is creating awaiting a COMMIT or ROLLBACK.
Thanks for the quick response.
Adding "END TRANSACTION" can have catastrophic consequences if my main app is running at the same time which sadly is how I found this problem in the first place.
But what are your thoughts on one of these fixes:
Option 1: It appears the sqlitebrowser understands that there are times when a transaction is not required.
SELECT BlahField FROM BladDb WHERE foo=0;
executes without enabling the "write changes" and "revert changes" buttons. So since sqlitebrowser knows not to start a transaction in that case why not add statements like "EXPLAIN" to the list of cases where a transaction is not created similar to how "SELECT" is handled? In fact instead of having a hard-coded list, as I am suggesting, why not call
int sqlite3_stmt_readonly(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
on the prepared statement to determine if changes will be made by that statement. Then only start a transaction in the cases where changes will be made.
Option 2: Since Transactions cant be nested perhaps DB Browser should consider using (SAVEPOINT, RELEASE, ROLLBACK TO) instead of (BEGIN, COMMIT, ROLLBACK). This might work better in the cases where I am using sqlitebrowser to look up something in the DB while my main app is running. Note to self: I should perhaps make this same switch in my app too.
Option 3: Let the user control the creation of transactions. Add an option to disable the current transaction approach built into sqlitebrowser thus forcing us users, who choose that option, to manually create transactions via the BEGIN or SAVEPOINT in those cases where we feel it is required. And if we don't then we get the default SQLite automatic transactions on every statement.
@rp- I have always thought that SQLite handled multiple processes accessing the DB perfectly fine. Closing the DB in SqliteBrowser resolved the issue and allowed my app to continue. Maybe this is something unrelated to the unrequired transactions topic so I should do some further investigation.

Desktop shortcuts were being copy to /usr/local/share/ instead of /usr/share/. According to the FreeDesktop.org specification (see http://standards.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/latest/ar01s02.html) it should not be a problem since it uses $XDG_DATA_DIRS environment variable, but it does not really work in GNOME. In their help files (see https://developer.gnome.org/integration-guide/stable/desktop-files.html.en) they guide developers to drop desktop files in /usr/share/ or ~/.local/share/.
I am running CentOS 7, with GNOME and the current directory works just fine for me. I don't object to the change of directory just saying it might not be needed or might be different for different distributions
@glawrence Although I tested only tested Linux Mint 17.1 (which uses Cinnamon), it seems to be a Gnome related problem. Did you check if there are cached desktop/icon files in your Gnome? (maybe from previous sqlitebrowser installations, dunno)
Also, it is important to note that, after this change, the sqlitebrowser icon just disappeared in my computer. If that happens to someone, just run "sudo gtk-update-icon-cache -f /usr/share/icons/hicolor/" to force the icon cache to update.
@justinclift Yes, the problem is with the current git master, I did not use the package manager from the distro because it is outdated. Also, I tested the installation with this proposed change, and everything worked as expected.
According to FHS (see http://refspecs.linuxfoundation.org/FHS_2.3/fhs-2.3.html#USRLOCALLOCALHIERARCHY), the correct place to store sqlitebrowser is /usr/local, and according to the FreeDesktop.org specification (see http://standards.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/latest/ar01s02.html) it should be also OK to store desktop files under /usr/local/share if it is listed on $XDG_DATA_DIRS variable (which is usually True).
So sqlitebrowser seems to be following the specification.
But, despite what these specifications says, Linux Mint 17.1 Cinnamon does not show desktop files stored under /usr/local/share in the menu (fortunately I installed the system yesterday, so I am with a clean installation). We still need to confirm if this issue affects other Debian based distros, or just Linux Mint.
Anyway, I am reporting this issue to Cinnamon developers, so we can track the source of it.
@DiegoQueiroz when I tested this I renamed sqlitebrowser.desktop to sqlitebrowser.xxxx when I did this the menu entry disappeared, when I changed the name back the menu entry returned. So I think this is probably a Mint issue. I don't have another GNOME install to hand, my openSUSE is running KDE.
I just confirmed that this issue also affects Ubuntu with Gnome (thanks to Professor J. Kinoshita, USP who kindly gave me access to his computer to test), so I think it's safe to say that this problem is not related only with Cinnamon or Linux Mint.
Hmm, sounds to me like some GNOME installs are adhering to the standard and others are not. So whilst DB4S is doing the right thing, it might be as well to take the pragmatic view and make the change
Well. If there is a set of systems that do not use
/usr/local/share/applications folder and a set that use it, so we need to
check the OS first and decide based on this.
Anyway, I am still not sure what systems really use
/usr/local/share/applications folder. Although I described it as possible
according to FreeDesktop standard, all tutorials and documentations I can
find around the web say to store .desktop files under
/usr/share/applications.

@justinclift Do you mean about the hardcoded path? I don't think there is anything wrong with the Makefile, since it ok to copy application files to /usr/local, no?
I'm not sure, but it seems to be also hardcoded somewhere when Gnome is installed (at least on Debian based systems).
I think the best workaround is to hardcode the path.
I understand it is a bad solution, but it should treated as a workaround, since some systems appear to be checking /usr/share folder only. We won nothing keeping the "right" relative path, if it does not work in Debian-based systems.
Another possible solution is to check if the /etc/debian_version file exists, if so, use the hardcoded path.
@justinclift just a thought, if problems are related to different base systems, we can check it via running "dpkg" command or "rpm" command to detect the base system (debian or redhat, but for other can be applied too). If cmand returns non-zero code means we are on wrong system. We can use nested if else with it.
But as I can see the problem is related to desktop entry,
1.  do we update cache after adding file to applications folder??
2. Permissions of. desktop file must be set to (acc to my knowledge 755).
3. ~/.local/share/applications is the diectory where only one user can have access to that entry, on the other hand /usr/share/applications will creare a global entry for all users.
For 1. Refer to below commands
desktop-file-edit
is used to modify an existing desktop file entry.
desktop-file-install
is used to install a new desktop file entry. It is also used to rebuild or modify the MIME-types application database.
desktop-file-validate
is used to verify the integrity of a desktop file.
update-desktop-database
is used to update the MIME-types application database.

Well On Linux Mint 17.2 it is working properly. So what is the problem ?? :)
Create a file "header" containing licence header .
Then :
for file in *.cpp *.h
do
cat header $file > $file.new
mv $file.new $file
done
~
Not needed, except (perhaps) in cases where the header is already present in a file you take in whole or in part from some other project. There are arguments for and against per-source-file notices; practice around this issue varies quite widely.
According to README.md, "DB Browser for SQLite is bi-licensed under the Mozilla Public License Version 2, as well as the GNU General Public License Version 3 or later." - it is not clear if this means that conditions of both licenses must be met at same time or that one or other license must be followed.
Thanks for clarification

Hope you don't mind @justinclift but I have added this to a wiki page now at https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Licensing as I thought this was worth documenting
Create Sample Table using "Import/Database from SQL file" function
> CREATE TABLE foo (x DOUBLE);
> INSERT INTO foo VALUES (9e999); -- +Inf
> INSERT INTO foo VALUES (-9e999); -- -Inf
> INSERT INTO foo VALUES (9e999 / 9e999); -- NaN: gets converted to NULL
This foo table has these values
> '-Inf'
> 'NULL'
Export foo table to SQL using "Export/Database to SQL file" function. This SQL Statement generates error on "Inf".
> CREATE TABLE foo (x DOUBLE);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (Inf);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (NULL);
I think that this is right. What do you think about this?
> CREATE TABLE foo (x DOUBLE);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES ('-Inf');
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (NULL);

It would be great if the column order during csv import could be changed. If the order of the columns in the target database doesn't match the source database, swapping the columns around manually is somewhat difficult.
Well, the problem is that csv import ignores column names in the csv file
and assumes the order is the same. In my situation this was not so. I
resorted to fixing the sql export as fixing the csv file was too much work.
But as a csv importer is already present, a dialog allowing the user to
arrange the csv columns before import would make sense.
I'm able to change the column order during a csv import in the latest master.
When exporting the database to SQL with the purpose of importing the data from one of the tables via SQL to another database, it would be extremely helpful if the columns were named in the INSERT statement. This would make the insert work even if the columns were in a different order in the target database (my situation),
I can solve it by replacing the INSERT word like this:
INSERT INTO `SomeData` VALUES (1,34,37,463);
to:
INSERT INTO `SomeData` (col1,col2,col3,col4) VALUES (1,34,37,463);
I would be nice if this tool could do this automatically.
It would be nice to select multiple cols and get them all resized in 1 go as has been implemented here:
https://forum.qt.io/topic/16047/solved-qtableview-resize-of-several-columns/6
SqliteBrowser allows using WITHOUT ROWID only for INTEGER column.
SQLite does not have this limitation:
https://www.sqlite.org/withoutrowid.html

BLOB data imported from file is not typed BLOB but TEXT.
We can replicate by following way.
1. create table
``` sql
CREATE TABLE 'Sample' ('ID' INTEGER, 'Image' BLOB, PRIMARY KEY(ID))
```
1. add new record on "Browse Data" tab
2. update 'Image' data by importing image file(e.g. jpg file) on 'Edit database cell'
3. query type of 'Image' data, and get TEXT type
``` sql
SELECT typeof(Image) FROM Sample
```
Maybe, the reason of this issue is DBBrowserDB::updateRecord(sqlitedb.cpp) method.
Imported data for update bind by sqlite3_bind_text without reference to actual (or estimated) data type.

Yes, I guess #229 is caused by same problem, too.
Thanks. That solves my problem, completely.
But, I worry about column that has multiple data type.
Now, we cannot insert TEXT data to BLOB column.
I think that use of such column is not good practice.
But, SQLite accepts such column by right.
For example, if we execute following SQL to last DB,
``` sql
INSERT INTO 'Sample' (ID, Image) Values(2, 'some text');
```
We get text value on Image column.
I think best solution is data type is switched according to 'Edit database cells' dialog.
Maybe, data type should not be decided by column type, but user's decision.

```
appstream-util validate sqlitebrowser.desktop.appdata.xml
sqlitebrowser.desktop.appdata.xml: FAILED:
‚Ä¢ tag-invalid           : <url> type invalid [unknown]
‚Ä¢ style-invalid         : <image> has vertical padding [https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/raw/master/images/sqlitebrowser.png]
‚Ä¢ style-invalid         : <image> has horizontal padding [https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/raw/master/images/sqlitebrowser.png]
‚Ä¢ style-invalid         : <li> is too short [Search records]
Validation of files failed
```
A url without a type is invalid (perhaps you meant type="bugtracker") and the other issues are just style warnings that would go away using validate-relax. Thanks!
@justinclift We rely on there being no alpha padding around the screenshot so we can scale it to fit the application area. This means the screenshots have to be taken without any kind of "fuzzy border" -- or you can remedy this in GIMP/Photoshop. Also, the screenshot is supposed to be what it looks like on Linux :) See http://people.freedesktop.org/~hughsient/appdata/#screenshots for more details; thanks.
@justinclift Any screenshot is better than no screenshot, but I'd really like the application installer to look sexy and coherent. If you need space I can host a static image somewhere, although I'd much prefer this was in your control for obvious reasons. If it helps, about half of the apps with AppData have the screenshot in the VCS :)
@hughsie I understand what `<li> too short` means but inclined to ignore that, the text is a direct copy of the website. Is there a list of valid url types, I could not see anything at http://people.freedesktop.org/~hughsient/appdata/ ? I did try using the validator on the web page but it did not work.
@justinclift thanks for the new repo, do you know someone who could trim the existing image or make a new one?
@glawrence You can ignore the two short style warning in this case, it's a little redundant. The URL types are defined here: http://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/chap-Metadata.html#tag-url
@hughsie thanks. I was thinking of adding GitHub repo as a second homepage but it is easy to get to from the main website, so will add a link to issues as a bugtracker. I guess once I fix the url we could run with this right? Or should we really fix the image first?
By the way, the xml file lands in /usr/local/share/appdata/ so is that okay?
@glawrence Fixing the screenshot can be done whenever, but I'd obviously prefer it not be forgotten about :) /usr/local/share/appdata/ isn't ideal, but if if you install the .desktop file to /usr/local/share/applications I'm sure the packager is just doing a simple mv to get things in the right place already.

"Ideally, all screenshots should have a 16:9 aspect ratio, and should have a width that is no smaller than 620px. They should also be in be in PNG or JPEG format. PNG is the preferred format; JPEG should only be used when screenshots include large photographs or other images where a lossy format like JPEG may compress better."

Cheers,
There are some issues with the paging arrows in the bottom left.  One thing is just a little confusing at first.  You are doing something that is not typical UI.  I've never seen software that lets you scroll, and also tells you which lines are being displayed in just the viewable window, and also lets you page through the scrollable view.  Once I figured out what was going on, it is actually pretty cool.  But then I found that if I change the window size, then use those paging arrows, they don't give me correct results.  They seem to skip large amounts of records.  I would suggest first, of course, to fix that errant behaviour.  And then maybe add the word 'Viewing' before the range of rows displayed, or something to make it clear the user can either scroll to see more records, or use the arrows to jump scroll.
V3.5.1
OSX Yosemite 10.10.2
I think it might be a OS X thing, because I couldn't reproduce on Fedora. Will try on OS X when I get home as well. :)
Yeah, the buttons are supposed to scroll 100 records up/downwards, no matter the size of the window. So if the window is very small, it will appear to skip a lot of records, but it's just moving the selection by 100 records.
The arrows in the column headings to indicate sort direction are incorrect.  They are the opposite of what they should be.  An upward facing arrow means the sort is from smaller to bigger (or alphabetic).  A downward facing arrow means the sort is from bigger to smaller (or reverse alphabetic).
Take a look at the arrows in the column headers of folders on a PC or a Mac, or in Outlook, or any other common software that allows sorting by columns, and you will see they are using them the way I am describing, which is the opposite of how you are.
![screen shot 2015-03-19 at 10 03 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6746358/11ddd606-ce84-11e4-948f-348d0863c272.png)
![screen shot 2015-03-19 at 10 03 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6746359/11f58364-ce84-11e4-8e35-23688efddb50.png)
![screen shot 2015-03-20 at 5 36 46 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6751612/2c247f4e-cec3-11e4-8719-f4b73205fc4f.png)
INT = short for INTEGER it's written full in 'list_id' to make it (synonym) of ROWID
ref. https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html#rowid
It is sorting incorrectly for list_id too
![screen shot 2015-03-20 at 6 59 39 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6752832/b94f72f6-cece-11e4-842a-3b5dad50dabb.png)
The arrow shows the order you can change the current one to so the opposite of what is the "status quo"
Ok, I think I got this fixed.
Apparently the problem happened when opening a table for the first time (either by opening a database file or switching tables) and clicking on a header. Then the data were sorted correctly (based on the order from the SQL query), but the arrow was upside-down.
Would be great if you could do some tests :smile:

I think it's a Qt bug on OS X, because it works on Fedora:
![save_as](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3753623/6735536/1e5d94a4-ce5f-11e4-9fdf-c447a9f9bc13.png)
Will do some research when I get home :)
So this is really a [bug in Qt](https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-38427) on OS X. It also affects older versions like 4.8.5, although it's not mentioned in the bug report.
The files become clickable if you leave and enter the directory again after changing the filter.
Another workaround is not use the native file dialog. That works, but it will look a little bit weird.
Or perhaps subclass QFileDialog and force a refresh when changing filter, but might be too much for something not so critical.
What do you think? :smile:

Hello,
Start with a new DB and go to SQL tab and execute:
CREATE TABLE customer(
id INTEGER,
firstName TEXT,
middleName TEXT,
lastName   TEXT,
address TEXT,
contactNum TEXT
);
CREATE TABLE item(
id INTEGER,
name TEXT,
description TEXT
);
CREATE TABLE orders(
id INTEGER,
customerID INTEGER,
date TEXT,
);
CREATE TABLE item_order(
id INTEGER,
orderID INTEGER,
itemId  INTEGER,
quantity INTEGER,
);
After you execute this, save the db.

ANATR|Ana Trujillo Emparedados y helados|Ana Trujillo|Owner|Avda. de la Constituci√≥n 2222|M√©xico D.F.||05021|Mexico|(5) 555-4729|(5) 555-3745

I agree with https://github.com/rp-
Perhaps the uploader used some pre-UTF8 codePage
To check go to http://mysharepoint.org/Accounting/Lists/Client%20List/AllItems.aspx
This is really a problem with the data. In the header of the file it says UTF-8, but the characters are encoded in Windows-1252 or ISO 8859-1. Navicat probably uses one of them as fallback or something. But the specification states that only 3 encodings are valid, namely UTF-8, UTF-16le and UTF-16be.
Hmm I don't know much about encoding, but it's possible to detect invalid UTF-8 characters, yes. It could then default to some other encoding instead of invalidating them (which is what I think is currently happening). So I think it's doable, however it will probably require a lot of changes.
It's indeed rather tricky to make an educated guess. There are so many ways to encode/encrypt data. Navicat was lucky since 8859-1 (Latin-1?) is (almost was) one of the most common. If the developers are able to detect let's say four of five of those, they deserve a prize. I don't think it's worth all the effort though besides an increase in size...
Allow copying of info in About DB Browser, so it can be copied and pasted when sending bug and enhancement requests 351, 486, SQLCipher386 version and 351, 486, SQLite 3.8.8.2.
Also should in SQLCipher Version mention OPENSSL version?

@atoregozh can you try the nightly build tomorrow to see if the issue is fixed? The problem was that some of the values end with the CR character ('\r'), which was not escaped when exporting. Because we now accept it as a line ending character, I've changed the code to also escape them.

Hmm I think that folder it's hidden by default.
Run this on Terminal:
`mkdir ~/Downloads/cores`
then
`cp -R /cores/* ~/Downloads/cores`
Then check your Downloads folder, a new `cores` folder should be there with the interesting files. If you could upload them somewhere and send the link it would be great :smiley:

It would be great if you could upload it somewhere or send it to @justinclift so he could upload to his server. To build the .dmg, Qt comes with a deploy tool. You can run:

Hi,
it would be very relieving if there was the possiblity to store/load table definitions which then can be applied to tables which are imported from csv files.
It suits to my use case where a bunch of people are managing data in a csv file on google drive (since concurrent access is possible) which then needs to be imported in a certain sqlite databse. The data belongs to a certain table of that databse but everytime I import the csv file I also need to modify the table definition fitting to the original definition (and of course rename that table and remove the older table, to perform the replacement). One alternative solution would be to somehow enable importing of csv data directly in a already existing table (column name matches needs to be checked and eventually duplicates omitted of course).
