@rp standard line ending of Mac is LF since the beginning of 21st century :-)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline#Representations
Perhaps for next milestone you may create an option in the menu where users may choose the EOL symbol of their system?
I forgot to add that this bug wasn't just for csv files but also for text files as well. When I tried importing a text file, I had the same 1 row with many fields instead of several rows and several columns.
@atoregozh could you provide a sample file?
The code works with LF and CRLF line endings, even if the file uses both. However, as @rp- mentioned it doesn't work with the old CR line endings, so perhaps your editor has that as default. TextWrangler, for instance, offers the ability to save with the three.
Also, could anyone enlighten me and explain how to know what line endings were used in a csv file? In order to create the file, I just manually typed the rows in excel and saved it As .csv file.
Yes, that's using only CR.
The easiest way to check is to use a editor that shows that information (Sublime Text does and IIRC so does TextWrangler) or open Terminal and run:
`$ file <filename>`
The output for your file is:
`handle.csv: ASCII text, with CR line terminators`
However, apparently this is a bug (or a feature?) of Office for Mac when exporting to CSV. I don't know if there is a setting to change that, but you can convert the line endings to a more common format by using a text editor that supports it (like the ones I've mentioned) or checking [here](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline#Conversion_utilities) for some command line tricks.
Hmm I did some searches and apparently there's no setting in Excel to change that. Don't know why would they choose this behavior though...
Anyway, from what I've seen it would be easy to also accept only CR as the line-ending character. What do you guys think?
As for Sublime, it's showing correctly: Windows uses CRLF. CR was used by Mac OS until version 9 and starting with OS X it switched to Unix line endings (LF).
I think it should be working now.
By mistake I referenced and commented in the other CSV issue... it's right next to this one :smile:
@justinclift we already cover cases where there's a non-empty string between the separators :wink:
@atoregozh Yeah, you can test tomorrow with the nightly build. It won't be in the stable version though -- if everything works out it should be in the next release.
The line endings are actually part of the file contents, so Sublime is telling you that this file uses the character '\r' to indicate a line break. OS 9 text editors added that character to the files when saving them to represent a newline. OS X editors now add '\n' instead, which is the same character used by Unix systems. So Sublime just shows what character(s) the file contains that represent a newline, along with the most common OS family to first set that character as the default for files read/written by that OS family tools.

Table:
BEGIN TRANSACTION;
CREATE TABLE `table1` (
`Field1`    TEXT
);
INSERT INTO `table1` VALUES ('testing');
INSERT INTO `table1` VALUES ('123');
INSERT INTO `table1` VALUES ('87654');
COMMIT;
Query:
select \* from table1 where CAST(Field1 AS Text) LIKE '%2%'
1 Rows returned from: select \* from table1 where CAST(Field1 AS Text) LIKE '2%' (took %3ms)
The % in front of '2%' is dropped and no results are returned.
Ver 3.5.1
SQlLite version: 3.8.8.2
Did another test and ran from the sqlite3 cli - working fine.
sqlite> select \* from table1 where CAST(Field1 AS Text) LIKE '%2%';
123
Running Win 10 Preview build if it helps. (10.0.9926) - 64 bit.
Some more info which hopefully points to where the problem could be:
like '%6% - working.
like '%3% - is changed to like '6%';
like '%2%'; - is changed to like '2%';
like '%1%'; - is changed to like '7%';
Very odd. :) Also tried on Win7 - same issue so it doesnt seem to be OS related.
I think I've got it. :smile:
The "%2" was being seen as a placeholder by QString::arg() when doing replacements.
Great stuff. That was quick - thanks. Will check in the nightly tomorrow.
Tested on the latest nightly. Now working. Thanks a lot guys!

Tell me what you think:
I thought about two cases, one where the user's locale has a corresponding translation and the other where it doesn't.
For the first case, supposing that the language is German, I thought that it would be more informative to just show "German" selected instead of "System Language", because there's a German translation and the application would be in German. For the second case, I thought that showing "English" right away instead of "System Language" would also be more informative because it indicates clearly that there's no translation in the user's language and that it has defaulted to English.
And the language names will always be in English. This was meant to prevent cases where the users couldn't find their languages because the program somehow started in a strange language (perhaps it would be better to show the name of the languages in the native version?).
(BTW, I have to add some comments to the code about this).
@rp- I reverted the changes but unfortunately using the native version turned out to be a no can do. That would break compatibility as the methods were introduced in Qt 4.8.

The argument count (first parameter) is a reference, and thus must be kept alive for the whole lifetime of the QCoreApplication instance, as also the Qt apidocs say.
Also properly create a "string array" for the actual args, instead of badly casting a string to that.
This fixes sporadic crashes in this test, for example as seen for some architectures in the Debian build of 3.4.0: https://buildd.debian.org/status/logs.php?pkg=sqlitebrowser&ver=3.4.0-1 & http://buildd.debian-ports.org/status/logs.php?pkg=sqlitebrowser&ver=3.4.0-1 (click on texts in the "Result" column to see the logs).
I've noticed that the types available when creating a new field in a table are limited.  Is there any goal to support datetime?
SQLite does not have a storage class set aside for storing dates and/or times.
"Error adding new record: near ")":syntax error". I don't know where to search the problem.
Please make a repair function, fix this or show the position of the illegal record. https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/13673400/test.sqlite
After "compact database" the button "write changes" is disabled.
The problem is probably in your schema SQLite does not recognize the types 'BOOL' nor 'DATETIME
sqlite> select \* from spieleliste;
Name                                      Hersteller    Genre             F  installiert       Pl  durchgespiel  Sonstiges /   Bewertung   Erscheinungsdatum
---
Command & Conquer 3                       EA            Strategie         O  1                 PC  kA
sqlite>
"installiert" BOOL DEFAULT (0)
"Erscheinungsdatum" DATETIME
See https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html#tablecoldef
and https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#affinity

So I've implemented the changes proposed by @MKleusberg and the behavior is the following: it adds the suffix "[System language]" when the language has a corresponding translation and, if that's not English, it adds "[Default language]" to English. It also moves the selected language to the top.
However, for English the resulting text is "English (United States) [System language]", which seems kinda ugly to me. It's also a little long, so the combo box width would need to be increased. Any suggestions here?

It's actually quite easy to add them; QComboBox supports passing a QIcon() along with the data, so it would be a matter of including the images in the resource file. Of course, a image file would need to be added for every new translation.

Hello, I do not think that this patch is to be applied in the code base, it was necessary for me to make a clean install on FreeBSD. Nevertheless, it may be possible to perform a modification of the code to be compatible with all systems. Indeed, SqliteBrowser search the directory "translations" where it is installed (local dir or install dir /usr/[local]/bin).
Now it is in my view a mistake when it is installed, it must be in the directory of application-related documents (/usr/[local]/share). If the patch is to be applied, it should probably create a variable in CMake replacing %%DATADIR%% the right path (/usr/share/sqlitebrowser, /usr/local/share/ sqlitebrowser/, ./ etc.)
What did you think?

Please consider writing and installing an AppData file with the application description and some screenshots, else sqlitebrowser looks really bad in the GNOME and KDE Software Centers. We'd love to showcase more applications, but without the extra data file we can't.
See http://people.freedesktop.org/~hughsient/appdata/ for details; thanks!
Richard
I believe you can do this yourself via a pull request, so why not do it yourself, you seem to know what is required?
Rather than use developer time on this, I reckon someone else could help with this, if you. I would be happy to give it a go if there are no other volunteers and it is agreed this is a good thing.
Right, I could indeed do a pull request. There are three main reason I've asked upstream maintainers to do this rather than just submit something myself:
- You probably know the application inside out, e.g. how to take screenshots to fully show off all the features that would take many weeks of me using to find out.
- You can update the description and screenshots yourself when you add new features or port the UI to a new toolkit.
- Time; so far 473 upstream projects[1] have written AppData files, and I simple can't scale myself to do all that.
Also, according to https://alt.fedoraproject.org/pub/alt/screenshots/f22/matrix.html sqlitebrowser doesn't have any keywords in the .desktop file, which means that searching for it in the software center is going to be harder.
[1] https://alt.fedoraproject.org/pub/alt/screenshots/f22/status.html -- warning, BIG HTML page

Hello, I checked it out right now. Works great. Thanks. :)
I know that the preferred method for compiling is cmake, but I tried to compile through Qt Creator with qmake and had problems with the libraries because I was using shadow build.
Besides, of course, disabling shadow build, another solution I found was to use the OUT_PWD variable instead of the PWD variable when declaring the libs path. The code looks like this:
``` qmake
LIBPATH_QHEXEDIT=$$OUT_PWD/../libs/qhexedit
LIBPATH_ANTLR=$$OUT_PWD/../libs/antlr-2.7.7
LIBPATH_QCUSTOMPLOT=$$OUT_PWD/../libs/qcustomplot-source
```
This variable is equal to PWD when shadow build is disabled and equals to the build directory when it‚Äôs enabled, so it should keep the current behavior but add support for shadow build.
Of course, although it worked on OS 10.9.5 with Qt 5.4, I‚Äôm not sure whether this variable is always valid in every version. This would require some checking (if empty, if valid, etc.).
Anyway, what are your thoughts about this change?
If this works only for higher versions of OSX (I for one have 10.6.8) DB browser for SQLite can't claim anymore to be compatible for 10.6 thru 10.10; in and of itself not a bad idea. Happy holidays y'all!
The age old problem of moving forward and remaining backward compatible, which has no simple answer! Personally I would vote for sticking with one release branch, ie not maintaining multiple major versions, moving forward to Qt5.4 etc and maybe leaving an old release available for those that need it. Allowing easy building in QtCreator might actually help with development and new comers getting started.

SQLite by default uses 64-bit: https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html
<quote>
Except for WITHOUT ROWID tables, all rows within SQLite tables have a 64-bit signed integer key that uniquely identifies the row within its table. This integer is usually called the "rowid".
</quote>

Seem to work fine, GJ.
The problem is that the CMakeLists.txt for the unit tests doesn't include the PreferencesDialog class files. I think that including them there would probably cause issues because they include the `ui_PreferencesDialog.h`, which is automatically generated.
I don't know if there are better options, but what could be done is either pass the NULL color to the model once it's set or surround the code that calls `PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue()` with preprocessor checks, where the checked macro would be defined in the unit tests CMakeLists.txt (e.g. check if this is not a unit test build).
But the code to change the color worked nice here. :+1:
(A fix that I propose: according to the [Qt documentation](http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-4.8/qt.html#ItemDataRole-enum), BackgroundColorRole is obsolete and BackgroundRole should be used instead.)

`timestamp` INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT (strftime('%s','now'))

=(expresion)

en mi caso en particular podr√≠a entrar

=(strftime('%s','now'))
```

if(!( (ch == '\'' || ch == '"') && new_value.trimmed().endsWith(ch)  ))
{
if ( ch == '=' && new_value.trimmed().endsWith(')') && new_value.trimmed().at(1) == '(' )
new_value = new_value.trimmed().substring_function_I_dont_know(1);  // get rid of '='

```
No conozco QT ni C++, pero es algo as√≠.

Gracias.
Hello
DB Browser (DBB) supports default values, i.e. values as defaults, but NOT functions (expressions).
In the example I post, the column name is "timestamp", type INT, and must defaults to the current datetime in UTC, _as integer_. Because type affinity, SQLite converts this expression to integer with this SQL form:
```
timestamp INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT (strftime('%s','now'))
....
```
But, when I enter the expression `strftime('%s', 'now')` in the "default" column of the DBB **Table Editor** (not in the "Execute SQL" tab), DBB converts this to the text `'(strftime(''%s'', ''now''))'` and then generate this SQL:
```
timestamp INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT '(strftime(''%s'',''now''))'
```
of course, SQLite replaces the timestamp field with the literal string (strftime('%s','now')), and not the _numeric_ value returned by this function.
I hope I have been clear,
thanks.
Sorry, perd√≥n por la demora.
Acabo de probar la versi√≥n en desarrollo de 13-Dec-2014 02:14
Tiene un peque√±o detalle: al abrir la tabla para _modificar_ la estructura, el signo '=' no se lee. Si el esquema se guarda sin editar un campo calculado, el campo se mantiene; pero si se modifica, hay que agregarle el caracter '=' nuevamente para que el editor lo reconozca como una funci√≥n.
Aparte de eso, que supongo ser√° sencillo de corregir, al parecer funciona perfecto :thumbsup:
Anexo 3 im√°genes con la prueba que hice.

Hi.
If you mean that it is necessary "=()" to indicate that the default value is a function, I think so.
The point is: When the schema (of the table) is re-open for edit, the SB analyzer does not recover the equal sign, and if the developer changes the default field, he/she must reenter the sign for the analyzer recognizes the changed default value as a function. It is not serious, but it is uncomfortable.
The first time it happened to me I did a quick change to the default for the strtest field, and the query did not returns the results I expected. When I checked the schema, I realized that SB had kept the default value as text, and I to re-edit the schema to add the '=' and remove the duplicate quotes.
ok, I test it tomorrow

I am trying to convert an existing MySQL DB to sqlite.  Being an optimist, I first tried an "ansi-compatible" export from the MySQL DB for one table, created (and saved) a new DB in sqlitebrowser and then tried running some of the Export file.  The result is that sqlitebrowser just hangs.
I was hoping to see it report a syntax error or something like that so I could go about massaging the sql exported from MySQL so I could do my conversion.
The SQL I tried to run in sqlitebrowser was the following:
``` sql
SET time_zone = "+00:00";
/*!40101 SET @OLD_CHARACTER_SET_CLIENT=@@CHARACTER_SET_CLIENT */;
/*!40101 SET @OLD_CHARACTER_SET_RESULTS=@@CHARACTER_SET_RESULTS */;
/*!40101 SET @OLD_COLLATION_CONNECTION=@@COLLATION_CONNECTION */;
/*!40101 SET NAMES utf8 */;
--
--
-- --------------------------------------------------------
--
-- Table structure for table `posts`
--
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS "posts" (
"post_id" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
"topic_id" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"forum_id" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"poster_id" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"icon_id" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"poster_ip" varchar(40) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_time" int(11) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_reported" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"enable_bbcode" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
"enable_smilies" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
"enable_magic_url" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
"enable_sig" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
"post_username" varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_subject" varchar(255) CHARACTER SET utf8 COLLATE utf8_unicode_ci NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_text" mediumtext CHARACTER SET utf8 COLLATE utf8_unicode_ci NOT NULL,
"post_checksum" varchar(32) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_attachment" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"bbcode_bitfield" varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"bbcode_uid" varchar(8) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_postcount" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
"post_edit_time" int(11) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_edit_reason" varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_edit_user" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_edit_count" smallint(4) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_edit_locked" tinyint(1) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_visibility" tinyint(3) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_delete_time" int(11) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
"post_delete_reason" varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
"post_delete_user" mediumint(8) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
PRIMARY KEY ("post_id"),
KEY "forum_id" ("forum_id"),
KEY "topic_id" ("topic_id"),
KEY "poster_ip" ("poster_ip"),
KEY "poster_id" ("poster_id"),
KEY "post_username" ("post_username"),
KEY "tid_post_time" ("topic_id","post_time"),
KEY "post_visibility" ("post_visibility")
) AUTO_INCREMENT=51587 ;
```
Ideally sqlitebrowser should report what the error(s) is/are rather than just hanging.

Just a status update: I've managed to integrate Sparkle into the app, but not without adding code. I needed to add a small Object-C++ source file to call the Sparkle methods. Sparkle also requires packages to be signed and does a bunch of checks to avoid tampered updates so the .plist files required some changes as well.
Anyway, it was just the basic integration; I still need to look at Sparkle's code to see what options they provide and run more tests.

Opening a db file with a table like this crashes SqliteBrowser:
``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1 (
id1,
id2,
PRIMARY KEY(id1, id2)
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```
The crash happens at `sqlitetypes.cpp:391`. That line fails because `tab.findPk()` returns `-1` as it can't find a single primary key column.
``` cpp
Table CreateTableWalker::table()
{
Table tab("");
if( m_root ) //CREATE TABLE
{
‚Ä¶
while(s != antlr::nullAST)
{
// Is this a 'without rowid' definiton?
if(s->getType() != sqlite3TokenTypes::WITHOUT)
{
‚Ä¶
} else {
tab.setRowidColumn(tab.fields().at(tab.findPk())->name()); // <-- Line 391, Probably faulty
}
}
}
return tab;
}
```
```

Looks like it crashes with a table like this as well:
``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1 (
id1,
PRIMARY KEY(id1)
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```
This however works:
``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1 (
id1 PRIMARY KEY
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```
A lot of the code seems to depend on the existence of a single column primary key. When there's no rowid, the software kind of emulates one using the primary key (it only supports integer primary keys because of that behaviour). This obviously fails with composite primary keys.
I reckon quite some code would have to be redesigned in order to fix this issue.
So @justinclift unfortunately I don't have enough understanding of SqliteBrowser's inner workings to efficiently tackle this. This may be better done by someone who's familiar with the codebase, as it doesn't look like a simple fix.
I hope I could help you by pointing out the source of the malfunction.
I tried 3.4.0 on Windows (two different machines) and Linux, and the current master branch @1ce33792c534f7228fd888d0b27f5abdc51c8c28 on Linux.
Hm‚Ä¶ Are you sure you used a table having without rowid _and_ a multi-column primary key? As far as I can see, the code doesn't handle this case at all.
Weird‚Ä¶ Now I can't reproduce it with the examples I posted any more. I still have a db file that crashes though, I'll see if I can strip it.
So I can't reproduce the crash with my examples any more. The following table however still crashes:
``` sql
CREATE TABLE test (
key TEXT NOT NULL,
value TEXT NOT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY(key)
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```
``` sql
CREATE TABLE test (
key TEXT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY,
value TEXT NOT NULL
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```
``` sql
CREATE TABLE test (
key TEXT NOT NULL,
value TEXT NOT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY(key)
);
```
Yes that fixed it. I'm still sure I had crashes with the first examples I posted, but the last one is fixed, and I can't reproduce the others. Thanks!

I have a big database in mind that will be in sqlite.
And the most common data fill scenario would be the following:
There are 2-3 dictionary-tables that store dictionary entires, lots of them.
And there will be 1 table that will tie these entries together.
Obviously, this combination-table will have only id's from dictionary-tables, but it's so difficult to first input dictionaries, and they jump between tabs trying to memorize id's while pasting them to combination table.
I understand this probably isn't any close to a possible priority, but if there was only a way to say 'this cell of tableA can have only id's of tableB rows', but when I try to type something into tableA cell - show a dropdown of not-yet-added rows from tableB so I would be able to pick a row by the name, and UI would just add a correct id. This will simplify managing data a lot.

from Table1

This is a feature request to allow Insert/Update/Delete user interface capability for Views on Browse Data tab.
Views are normally read-only in SQLite, however, SQLite supports using triggers on Views, which handle the write operations attempted against the View. When this is the case, the absence of a user interface for editing the view means you have to write SQL code to do so.
To avoid confusion, you might consider interrogating existing triggers for an "...INSTEAD OF [INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE] on <Viewname>..." trigger to determine what user interface options to expose. But if this is too complex, it might just be better to expose the options and return the result from the database engine, whether that's an error (because the view is read-only and doesn't have a trigger for the action) or otherwise. Of course this may conflict with your easy-to-use design philosophy (some users might dislike having the user interface indicate that edits are possible when they are not), in which case I guess the enhancement should be rejected.
It is been two Years, can we reopen this issue?
Consider this database:
```
BEGIN TRANSACTION;
CREATE TABLE Foo (a, b, c);
INSERT INTO `Foo` (a,b,c) VALUES (1,2,3);
CREATE TRIGGER update_bar
INSTEAD OF UPDATE OF a ON Bar
BEGIN
UPDATE Foo SET a = NEW.a
WHERE b=NEW.b;
END;
CREATE VIEW Bar AS SELECT a, b FROM Foo ORDER BY b;
COMMIT;
```
With `sqlite3` It is legit to write:
```
```
However, it is not possible to do it so on a View on `DB Browser for SQLite`.

I've been using your SQLite Browser software for about some months and just updated to your new program version. Generally I enjoy your software a lot, but recently I've been a bit disappointed about editing options for views:

I would suggest you to implement a context menu option "CREATE TO" (similar to SQL Server) that creates a SQL file with CREATE VIEW SQL. Alternatively you could add options "Copy CREATE VIEW to Clipboard" or "Copy CREATE VIEW to new Query Tab".

Here is what I mean for "Database Structure" tab. Just change `role == Qt::DisplayRole` to `role == Qt::DisplayRole || role == Qt::ToolTipRole`. That's the tooltip I mean. Sorry for my bad English. :smiley:
``` cpp
QVariant DbStructureModel::data(const QModelIndex& index, int role) const
{
if(!index.isValid())
// Get the item the index points at
QTreeWidgetItem* item = static_cast<QTreeWidgetItem*>(index.internalPointer());
if(role == Qt::DisplayRole)
else if(role == Qt::DecorationRole)
return item->icon(index.column());
}
```
That's what I need. Thanks a lot!! :+1:

I want to export a reference table from a development environment and import it into the production database.
When I export a TEXT field that contains a string that can be interpreted as a number it is exported without quotation marks. Unfortunately that means that leading '0' characters are lost when I execute the resulting SQL to import it again. The string is changed.
Example of an exported table below. Note: the sensor_id column is TEXT and the value in the first row is '0000000000000001', but during the export the quotation marks are lost and during a subsequent import (executing the SQL) the value changes to '1', which is a very different string. The second row works fine, since it has the string '28C078480500001B' properly within quotation marks.
CREATE TABLE "sensor_descr" (
`sensor_id`     TEXT,
`sensor_descr`  TEXT,
`sensor_nick`   TEXT
);
INSERT INTO `sensor_descr` VALUES(0000000000000001,'Broken Example','broken');
INSERT INTO `sensor_descr` VALUES('28C078480500001B','Working Example','works');
COMMIT;
This problem occurs both in version 3.0.2 that is available in the OpenSuse repository and in the latest source downloaded and compiled from scratch just now (23rd Oct 2014).
Thanks a lot for looking into this so quickly. That's a good motivation to keep putting effort into meaningful bug reports. Thanks for a great little tool!
While editing a table definition, I set a default value and later I wanted to stop using that default value and deleted the content of it, but there's no way to "clear" the default flag, it continues using the DEFAULT clause with empty string as default value. I understand that under determined conditions you could need a empty string value as default, but what if you want to remove that default value?
I see two solutions:
- a new flag column should be added to determine if the user wants to use the default value (and activate it automatically if a default value is added, and stop using the default flag when it's unchecked
- add a context menu so you can revert the default value to undefined via right click over the field
Any other solution is welcome, of course :) I am just brainstorming a little
Workaround: remove the field and add it again (it's not much info to remember, but it's a little bothering if you have data on the table :)
I think this issue can be flagged as enhancement
Sure, will try along the weekend
Cheers

I come back to you with a long time later after the request. I am very sorry, I have been busy and forgot to look after this.
So, to remind the request was to create a simple form view for SQLite browser.
They are working almost the same way, but with a simpler way for Bento with a little more graphic features, so I made screenshots of it with Skitch that let me comment them.
Bento has been discontinued, and Mac users are angry about this FileMaker decision, it was also an SQLite based database set, so a Bento database could maybe even imported in SQLite browser.
It could so fill the need, and also give a mire powerful free product available as a multi-plateforme On Linux, Mac and Windows. Glom for Windows is outdated, the Mac version needs to compiled with Mac Ports, it is unstable and not easy at all ‚Ä¶
SQLite browser comes there has a better simple product and powerful anyway. It has a nice GUI, and it is very stable and easy to use or to install. So it could be the way to make everybody happy.
The idea is to have a simple view form to manage the datas and having a GUI which is simple and pleasant to enter the datas for the end user.
It should be possible to organize easily the way the fields are displayed and which ones could be visible.
It shouldn't let you manage complex features.

Hi, no sorry it doesn't fix the issue. Ignore what I said originally though. After looking at it again I think  it's actually just the second issue I mentioned, all other faults updating the table seem to stem from that.
When opening a table sqlitebrowser adds single quotes to default values: adding a second pair of single quotes if they exist already. I don't know how things work under the hood yet but if sql is being executed it's failing because of the extra single quotes ( eg. DEFAULT ''any data''), giving a binary data error.
Removing the default value or it's original quotes _fixes_ the sql generated so the table can be updated.
Should I delete the misleading info from the OP?
Hi, yep, I can do that :)
Hi, the latest build fixes this issue. However a new problem has been introduced. If you delete a default value then the SQL generated still includes the _DEFAULT_ keyword and an empty value, for columns that have had default values removed.
CREATE TABLE `TestTable` (
`No`    TEXT,
`Nationality`   TEXT DEFAULT '',
`Position`  TEXT,
`Firstname` TEXT DEFAULT '',
`Surname`   TEXT,
`Loan`  TEXT,
);.
In the textbox that had the default value removed, empty single quotes are inserted by the app.
---
On writing the changes and opening the table for modification again, not all the default values have been persisted...
CREATE TABLE `TestTable` (
`No`    TEXT,
`Nationality`   TEXT DEFAULT '',
`Position`  TEXT,
_`Firstname`    TEXT, missing default_
`Surname`   TEXT,
`Loan`  TEXT,
);
As you can see, _Firstname_ is missing the app generated default.
Sure, I'm more than happy to check out new builds :)

The discussion on this reminded me of Python, so I have read https://docs.python.org/3/library/csv.html and they refer to the same RFC4180 from IETF, so that's a good start. However they have an Excel dialect, so clearly acknowledge that you have to do stuff differently with Excel. This might be a useful reference when investigating this issue.
Yes, so my guess is you would have an initial choice of "Standard CSV", "MS Excel Compatible", "Custom", where the custom option allows you to change delimiter, row terminator, etc for those that need it and the first two are easy for most people.
Oh and last I looked when numbers get over 15 digits Excel truncates, so you might need to handle that twist!
Sorry if it seems like I am being a pain but I have had pain in the past so just sharing my experience to hopefully benefit all. For me Python is a good place to look as it is cross platform and well established.
Guys, it‚Äôs your call but I think keeping things simple and not overdoing it would be a wise strategy.
- ```
First and foremost the goal should be producing the same default result as sqlite3 does ‚Äì that is the reference most people would expect
```
- ```
I did not experience Excel breaking the standard CSV, the only problem I ever encountered is that Excel does not auto-detect 64 bit Integers correctly, it treats them as Double. For these cases you can do a custom import in Excel.
```
- ```
The 15 digits truncation may only happen with manually created content ‚Äì if you export a double and read it back in that problem does not exist.
```
- ```
The double quote character is defined as ‚Äú, so you don‚Äôt really need to have a selection box for it if you elect to make them optional (means only use them when necessary for the field content)
```
- ```
Same goes for line ending. Just stick to CRLF.
```
Thanks
Jens

My table:
CREATE TABLE `test` (
`ID`    INTEGER NOT NULL,
`Name`  TEXT NOT NULL,
`ID2`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY(ID,ID2)
);
It is not possible to insert a record in Browse Date because there is a primary key with two fields and twice are NOT NULL

Sorry, same like #81
I would like to have a Date field, but it's not possible, as the types are limited to these on the combobox
SQLite does not need a field with date affinity. It's either edited and text like e.g.  '2014-09-20' or numeric (int if you prefer) 20140920. or even epoch.
All about it is in http://sqlite.org/lang_datefunc.html
Perhaps the developers of this awesome browser are willing if they have time to introduce some helping hand for you, but there are more issues with a certain form of priority.
I know how data types work in SQLite, the thing is that my database engine uses the field type to know how to treat/convert types to native data
Allowing you to write the field type instead of provide a non editable combobox with fixed values is not a big change at all
Priorities are relative to the importance of the problem to each one, and for me this has a certain form of priority. I also know that I have different workarounds to address this, but aren't straightforward at all
It's curious because on version 2, the product had a [...] button to add custom types! so seems that this feature was dropped somewhere :)
About adding it myself, I feel a little lost with the used tools, I already downloaded the code and QTCreator, but couldn't make it compile, need to investigate a little. I have two long holiday weeks ahead, so I will consider it if I can fight against this laziness :D

It appears that the table export to CSV builds the export file content first in RAM before writing it to the specified file. If the table is very large the process is hitting the 2GB RAM limit of Windows 32bit applications. Then it crashes. No file gets written at all.
Where do I find the nightly builds?
Ok, I did run the test and the crash is resolved. Monitored the memory usage in task manager all looks good.
However, I see now a different problem: All fields regardless of actual column type are exported as text, means in ‚Äúquotes‚Äù. That could cause trouble when reimporting the generated file in other tools, e.g. Excel but also increases file size substantially. In my case the same export run with sqlite3.exe produces a 341MB csv file while using sqlitebrowser produces 420MB. Other than that the content appears identical.
Example:
1,0,10.1349167,48.0175202,2.758584499,-0.0005592033267,10.1414681,48.01049,2.500045538,0.0,924.6688232,0.0005592033267,1,9,0
1,1,10.1414681,48.01049,2.5000453,0.0,10.1471049,48.0047975,2.675153971,0.0004602147965,760.9866943,0.0004602147965,1,9,0
Sqlitebrowser:
"1","0","10.1349167","48.0175202","2.758584499","-0.0005592033267","10.1414681","48.01049","2.500045538","0.0","924.6688232","0.0005592033267","1","9","0"
"1","1","10.1414681","48.01049","2.5000453","0.0","10.1471049","48.0047975","2.675153971","0.0004602147965","760.9866943","0.0004602147965","1","9","0"
Thanks
Jens
Yes, that works for my specific case because all fields are numbers. If I remember the CSV spec correctly, the quote character should only be used for fields which contain the separator character, so that the column structure is kept intact. I also just noticed that the line ending of the produced files are Unix style ‚Äì only \n. Should be platform default.
Thanks
Jens
I think the document should be right, but I am not 100% sure.
The spec says double quotes are optional as long as no special chars are in the field. So the current version is strictly correct, yet it creates trouble with Excel (it prevents automatic field type detection). Since Excel is a widely used tool AND avoiding unnecessary double quotes creates smaller files I would recommend removing them.
1.  Each field may or may not be enclosed in double quotes (however
some programs, such as Microsoft Excel, do not use double quotes
at all).  If fields are not enclosed with double quotes, then
double quotes may not appear inside the fields.  For example:
zzz,yyy,xxx
2.  Fields containing line breaks (CRLF), double quotes, and commas
should be enclosed in double-quotes.  For example:
bb","ccc" CRLF
zzz,yyy,xxx
3.  If double-quotes are used to enclose fields, then a double-quote
The spec says all files should be CRLF ‚Äì means Windows style. There is no ambiguity here. That should be an easy fix.
Thanks
Jens
On the Browse Data tab: It would really enhance keyboard navigation to have either (or) both the 'enter' and 'tab' keys move input focus to the next filter field. Currently 'tab' moves to the next data cell and 'enter' does nothing.

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4123228/4604315/6640d33e-5192-11e4-950d-d4c84d636a86.png)

And I'm still early. Build log indicates its still 0177155. I'll wait till tomorrow.
The file sqlitebrowser.exe.xz is actually an archive file, so you need to extract the exe from the archive before running. I suggest something like 7-Zip (http://www.7-zip.org/) for doing the extract. I just tried this and it worked fine for me.
Bottom line, tabbing between filter field works as I'd expect. Enter still
does nothing, not sure if that's important.
Thank you for making these kinds of improvements, it makes the tool awesome.
I could go either way. The filter gets applied on each character keypress so it's not like <enter> is required to start the filter. Plus back tabbing is supported with shift + Tab whereas using Enter to move between fields would imply Shift + Enter for moving backward and that does not seem idomatic.
I guess I lean toward leaving Enter unmapped.
Is it possible to make a toggle so that I can use the refresh button and still keep the filters I've entered?
That appears to have fixed it, thank you!
Export Database or Table to SQL or CSV - allow a user to export the schema only

Check box label:  "Export schema only"
Default check box condition: Unchecked
Warnings are called liked that, because they are mostly harmless. In this case those parameters are probably placeholders for future features. The developer(s) will know if I'm right.
Will it be possible to access more than one file in a session?
I tried an 'attach', but B4S (Browser for SQLite) seems not to support it. Perhaps in a future version?
Standard one can attach nine more databases and even 124 with runtime-options.
Ref: http://www.sqlite.org/limits.html#max_attached
I get
cannot ATTACH database within transaction: attach 'file:../db/main.sqlite:mode-ro' as dd;
I wrote
attach 'file:../db/main.sqlite?mode=ro' as dd;

``` sql
create table foo(id integer primary key, value text);

Thanks! Solved this issue.
Import table from a CSV file does not handle linebreaks in a field: If a field in the csv file contains a linebreak, the import function handles it as the start of a new record. A solution might be to take the number of fields per record into account as well.
I noticed this while importing a csv file from a third party.
ps. I find the "Import table from a CSV file" function brilliant anyways!
Hi Justin,
Thanks for mentioning this #84, I saw the same thing (spaces being removed) and I thought it had something to do with me Find-And-Replacing linebreaks.
Thinking of #84: it is removing all empty spaces where LEADING and TRAILING spaces is probably meant (and the latter is very usefull!).
Anyways, thanks a lot for this wonderful tool, I find myself using it a lot lately while making my (free!) apps.
Cheers,
Niels Cup
Niels Cup wrote: LEADING and TRAILING spaces is probably meant (and the latter is very usefull!).
I agree, however according to the standard _no_ (i.e.0, the digit) spaces at all should be removed. To be absolutely sure all text fields should be quoted either by ' or "
One time I noticed a CSV-file I copied and changed all commas by |, but there was a field with an unexoected | inside [luckily just exactly one record :-)] in order to create a SQLite-database.
Hi Justin,
I  tried the build below and I had some problems with it: I received a message: ‚ÄúError importing data. Message from database engine: table table1 has 39 columns but 40 values were supplied‚Äù. I would like to see the record number in this message so I am able to correct the csv file. I received this message with the original CSV file formatted like this: ‚Äúfield1‚Äù,‚Äùfield2‚Äù,‚Äùfield3‚Äù, ‚Äúetc‚Ä¶‚Äù.
I also have a version of this csv file which I have changed to a pipe separated file (field1|field2|field3|etc‚Ä¶) and I didn‚Äôt receive the error on this file, but I noticed the import is now very slow. I have a very large (third party) csv file, 104000 records. I started import, went away and came back after half an hour and the import was only at 52%. The previous version took only 2 or 3 minutes. Performance might not be an issue for smaller files (which would normally be the case).
I know CSV files are often unreliable, I have bumped into these same issues when writing my own import tools. For me the previous version (without the remove all spaces bug) was more workable than this version. In the previous version the import went pretty fast and succeeded. Afterwards I was able to see where the import jumped columns and I could manually remove the linebreaks in Excel.
Cheers,
Niels.
Hi Rene, the ‚ÄúDecoding CSV file..‚Äù is very slow. I have just tested (the decoding part) again, with my csv file 104000 records:
- Version 3.3.1 = fast meaning approx. 20 seconds for 104000 records
- Version master_git = slow meaning at 20% after 5 minutes
I have created a test.csv file, with only 10 records and a header (I cant attach the full file, it is 100mb‚Ä¶), just copy the records until you have 50.000 or 100.000 records .
I can‚Äôt send you the original file either because it is not my data, but the result is the same with this test file.
Kind regards,
Niels.

Hi! When I import a csv-file into a table every single space was deleted (v 3.3.0). Special characters are not displayed correctly even though in v 2.0 it worked fine. What happened? Is it my fault? Can I make any settings to avoid at least the space-deleting? Thanks a lot for your help!
In fact there is: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4180
As is written there spaces should not be ignored and use of double quotes
depends on system/application; M$ExCel goes it's own way...
wrote:
> Right now I can only give you 2 workarounds, until those bugs are fixed.
> 1. save your CSV file in the UTF-8 encoding, e..g with libreoffice
>    calc (character encoding can be set on export)
> 2. Quote all your strings with whitespaces in it, I don't know if
>    there is a CSV rfc or how strings in fields should really be handled, but i
>    guess we shouldn't throw away whitespace between field separaters if they
>    don't mess up the file format.

Hello folks,
After the excellent service on my last request, I have a couple more:
1. On the 'Database Structure' tab, could the schema be made to collapse along with the field list? As it is, the benefit of collapsing is rather lost when the schema is long and you can only see a few (or only one) tables on your window anyway.
2. On the results from running an SQL query, long fields (varchar and friends) should only be displayed up to some maximum length. Otherwise you have to do massive horizontal scrolling to see all your fields.
3. On SQL query results and table browsing, how about a right-click option to copy the value of the field into the copy buffer. At the moment you can accomplish this with browse data by double-clicking and copying from the 'Edit database cell' window, but you can't do it at all with query results.
Many thanks for your help. And let me know if it makes sense that I work on the code myself - I could do it, but would ultimately prefer to avoid one more learning curve!
Cheers, Jonathan
> makes sense to remove newlines while collapsed.

> On the results from running an SQL query, long fields (varchar and
> friends) should only be displayed up to some maximum length.
> Otherwise you have to do massive horizontal scrolling to see all
> your fields.
> ```
>
> Maybe we can add saving of column width like we do for the browse table,
> but there is no easy general solution for this.

> and copying from the 'Edit database cell' window, but you can't do

the field, and I'm sure others could think of more.

Hello,
Since version 3.2, sqlitebrowser reports an error on tables with the 'ASC' keyword in its primary key definition. For example, the a database consisting of the following table (created with sqlite3):
CREATE TABLE [Test]([Field] [int] NOT NULL, CONSTRAINT [Test_Constraint] PRIMARY KEY %28 [Field] ASC %29);
cannot be browsed or modified with sqlitebrowser. That is, browsing the table shows the correct number of records but no data in the records. Attempting to modify the table reveals that the entire table definition (apart from the table name) has been lost. Running sqlitebrowser from the command line returns:
I hope that's enough info to help someone diagnose the problem.
Thanks!

The DB has no data in it, just the schema: tables, triggers, views.
Opening it with _android-sdk-windows\platform-tools\sqlite3.exe_ works, so I tried to narrow it down.
If I drop these:
``` sql
drop table Category_Name_Cache;
drop table Item_Path;
```
I tried dropping only the triggers of these tables, but it was still crashing. So I suspect there must be something in the `CREATE TABLE`s.
Are you sure about that AUTOINCREMENT being the culprit?
The tables I dropped to make it not crash didn't have a PRIMARY KEY like that!
Note: I use `PRIMARY KEY(...)` format instead of `name type PRIMARY KEY` to be consistent among tables with singular/multiple keys. And because of this I don't know if I can put the AUTOINCREMENT anywhere else.
`ALTER TABLE ... RENAME TO` should take care of those contstraints, I don't think it's a good idea to restrict. http://www.sqlite.org/lang_altertable.html however renaming a table and updating `VIEW`s and `TRIGGER` bodies would be a nice feature if not already implemented.
@justinclift
Sure I'll try tomorrow, when will it be available (with timezone)?
> Maybe n "Novice mode" option set in preferences, would let us keep stuff simple for novices.
That's not a good idea in general, lot of features will be used by a really small userbase (hard to discover), for example Visual Studio has a nicely hidden "Advanced UI" option in a non-intuitive place: http://i.msdn.microsoft.com/dynimg/IC429789.jpg
I'd suggest an expander for advanced features if you decide to go ahead: http://qt-apps.org/content/show.php/ExpanderWidget?content=163843 novice users will see an "Advanced" header of the closed expand and think "Advanced features, beware", others will expand confidently and won't be scared.

I just realized that when I try to modify a table after a default value has been introduced, following changes are just ignored. They appear in the modify table window and the "query" on the bottom is updated, but if you hit OK, nothing else happens. I also realized that you usually get a little window after any change that dissapears very fast (I think that it reads "executing SQL" or something like that) but once you introduce a default value, that window doesn't appear anymore.
If you remove that default value, everything is working fine
I also realized that if you open the modify table again after setting a default value, it now appears as 'value' instead of just value (I mean, quoted)
Here you can see an example
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297845/3649297/1411fd66-1111-11e4-9248-468a12a2eb51.png)

I have multiple fields with default values and whenever I try to add a new field, the field is always 'Field7' and cannot be renamed. I just tried the Nightly Mac build 09-24-2014. This table is created with Doctrine2/ORM running on PHP5.6 PDO SQLite. I've just updated the table (using PHP5.4 PDO SQLite3 3.7.7.1) with new data without a problem.
Here's the table schema:
```
SQLite version 3.8.5 2014-06-04 14:06:34
Enter ".help" for usage hints.
sqlite> .schema
CREATE TABLE "movie" (
"id"  INTEGER NOT NULL,
"imdb"  INTEGER,
"status"  REAL NOT NULL,
"serie"  INTEGER,
"added"  INTEGER,
"updated"  INTEGER,
"watched"  INTEGER,
"title"  TEXT NOT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY ("id" ASC)
);
sqlite>
```
I've tested some other databases and none of them has the weird characters, so you're right that that has something to do with it. I've tried to replicate the weird characters without any luck. I've done some operations with PHP and Navicat but also no weird characters.
My conclusion is that most likely there's something wrong with my table, although PHP and Navicat has no problems with it. I believe that this issue can be closed.
About the weird characters in my database, that are just CR and LF instead of spaces in other SQLite3 databases I have inspected. It can be seen on this screenshot:
I took a quick look at the file format on http://www.sqlite.org/fileformat2.html but couldn't find any specifications there about the allowed characters in the creation text.
Maybe someone knows where to find more exact specifications of the file format?
I came across some other databases, tested and inspected them. Table creation text with LF and TAB characters works, data can be seen in the `Browser Data` tab.
Please ask if more screenshots would be helpful and also if you like to examine the database file itself. It's only 1MB.

homebrew has been updated with a brew of sqlitebrowser 3.2.0
All that is required to install from brew now is:
`brew install sqlitebrowser`
```
$ brew info sqlitebrowser
sqlitebrowser: stable 3.2.0, HEAD
http://sqlitebrowser.org
/usr/local/Cellar/sqlitebrowser/3.2.0 (4 files, 2.2M) *
Built from source
From: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/blob/master/Library/Formula/sqlitebrowser.rb
==> Dependencies
Build: cmake ‚úî
Required: qt ‚úî, sqlite ‚úî
```
```
$ brew install sqlitebrowser
==> Downloading https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/archive/sqlb-3.2.0.t
######################################################################## 100.0%
==> cmake . -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local/Cellar/sqlitebrowser/3.2.0 -DCMAKE_BU
==> make install
üç∫  /usr/local/Cellar/sqlitebrowser/3.2.0: 4 files, 2.2M, built in 57 seconds
```

Done. I see this morning it's now a work in progress (John building...)
Up until now, the DBBrowserDB:decodeCSV used to load the csv-file character by character using the getChar() method of the QFile-class.
Unfortunatelly, this approach caused multibyte-chars as used for UTF-8 encoding to be split and displayed incorrectly.
The fix uses the QTextStream-class to load the file line by line.
Every line is then again iterated character by character, before the old algorithm is applied. Using this approach, the characters are loaded and encoded properly. Splitting multibyte-chars is thus prevented.
Thank you for the feedback. I am happy that I can contribute something usefull to the project. As my schedule permits I will try to add and test your proposed changes and push them up this afternoon.
You are right, this might turn into a problem later. I must admit that I haven't worked with QT for a long time, so I might be a bit rusty ;-)
Exchanging it with inStream.readLine() should do the trick, thought.
I might have found a first bug. A colleague of mine build the program on a mac, and there it seemed to have messed up the separators, as columns are not separated properly anymore. As I've only tested on a windows-machine I didn't know before, but I will investigate the problem asap.
Ok, I've pushed a few more changes.
The line is now loaded using the readLine() command instead of the stream-operator. Also I've cleaned the code a bit up by removing unnecessary if-clauses and moved some of the variables into the outer-loop (as per request).
Finally, I've introduced an additional condition into the algorithm to detect blanks between separator and quote.
EDIT: Made a quick test on my Mac and everything seems to work. Even files with only one line are imported properly.

This is similar to issue #34, except using the construction `NOT LIKE`. Please note that using a regular `LIKE`, i.e. without negation, does work.
Example:
```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value NOT LIKE "prefix%")
);
CREATE TABLE working(
value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value LIKE "prefix%")
);
INSERT INTO not_working( value ) VALUES( "a" );
INSERT INTO    working( value ) VALUES( "prefixa" );
-- INSERT INTO    Working( value ) VALUES( "b" );
```
I'm using the test build posted in the comment by @justinclift in issue #34 on Windows 7.
Confirmed working now, also on my larger database :)
However, it appears to me that the underlying issue is that you are not fully implementing the grammar as specified by SQLite. For example, looking at the possible definitions for table constraints (http://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html -> column-def -> column-constraint -> expr), it seems to me that the same (specific) problem holds for "GLOB", "REGEXP" and "MATCH". Indeed, the following example again fails to display properly:
```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value NOT GLOB "foo")
);
CREATE TABLE working(
value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value GLOB "foo")
);
INSERT INTO not_working( value ) VALUES( "bar" );
INSERT INTO    working( value ) VALUES( "foo" );
```
The issue is that all of these expressions (and possibly more in the other comparison operators) may be prefixed by an optional "NOT" operator. However your current fix just allows "NOT LIKE" in addition to regular "LIKE" conditions, but it does not add the generic ability to say "NOT <expression>".
The same holds for the fix for issue #34, modifying the example leads to e.g.:
```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value NOT IN( "foo" ) )
);
CREATE TABLE working(
value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value IN( "foo" ) )
);
INSERT INTO not_working( value ) VALUES( "bar" );
INSERT INTO    working( value ) VALUES( "foo" );
```
Which again does not display properly.
I'm wondering whether this is intentional? (and how many more of these examples I can come up with ;)
Oh I see. I do notice that when I open the sqlite file again those shm and wal files reappear. Thanks for your answer!

@sammarcus wrote 'stupid question'. With the sole exception of the unasked there is no such thing as a 'stupid question'. Stupid answers however there are unfortunately too many...
Back on-topic: like someone said: by opening more than one session (e.g. more TerminalTabs) one can easily have more WA-L and/or SHM-files and investigate them with any tool/language (Perl is an easy example) capable of handling binary files. With the help of SQLite's doc you're able to analyze them and search for nugs and other reasons of corrupted databases.

I was also experiencing this problem on my Mac OS X 10.9.4:
``` bash
$ qmake
WARNING: Ignored (not found) '/Users/username/Documents/sqlitebrowser/libs/antlr-2.7.7/antlr.xcodeproj'

qmake -spec macx-llvm
make

How about "auto open last project" and "open project from command line" :question:
When using a CHECK constraint on a column of a table which uses the IN( ... ) syntax to check that the value exists in a known set of values, the resulting table does not appear to have any columns when viewed at the "Database Structure" tab. Inserting values will still work, as will querying the table manually, but the "Browse Data" tab will show rows without any columns or data.
Example:
```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
_id PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
);
CREATE TABLE working(
_id PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
);
INSERT INTO not_working( _id, value ) VALUES ( 1, 'a' ), ( 2, 'b' ), ( 3, 'c' );
INSERT INTO working( _id, value ) VALUES ( 4, 'a' ), ( 5, 'b' ), ( 6, 'c' );
```
I'm using version 3.1.0 on Windows 7.
Thanks for the quick fix! It now seems to work fine on my database :)

CREATE TABLE episode (episodeid integer primary key references filmitem (filmid),serieid integer not null references filmitem (filmid),seasonnb integer not null,episodenb integer no null,title varchar[max],foreign key (serieid) references serie (serieid));

Is there any reason sqlb does not contain a compiled osx sqlitebrowser.app in its release distribution?
Was thinking maybe a license issue or possibly a security signing which may prevent it running on other machines issue maybe?
You basically can copy the Qt framework files to your app bundle, and that's it. Examine the package for the older (sourceforge) app and you will see how it is done. I think I had some automated routines at one time to do this, but they were for Qt3, probably very different.
One note: in the previous version I used to include the sqlite3 source in the tree, and compile it with the program. But I see now that this has changed (reading cmake). So you are correct that you also need to include the lib.
But, in general, OSX bundles have this ability: you can include the libs inside the bundle directory and they will be searched first, and take precedence over the ones installed in the system.
For the Qt libs, you can use the included tool to simplify this:
http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-5/macosx-deployment.html

Same issue here with both versions. The problem seems to be in libsqlite3.0.dylib. How did you generate it? Did you do this on a machine running Mavericks?
Maybe this lib needs to be compiled/linked against an older version of the system frameworks in order to work on older OSX releases.
I am pretty sure the processor does not matter, XCode targets abstract this. The problem is most likely that you used/bundled a system version of libsqlite3 that is incompatible with what I have here. Did you copy this from your sytem folder, or compile it?
That is one of the reasons I used to add sqlite3.c to the builds, so you would have a static version on all platforms. Of course, it makes it difficult to update Sqlite and benefit from fixes (specially in the case of LInux builds). For OSX and Win this is really not an issue as you would have to replace the lib anyway.
Justin, try not including libsqlite3 in the archive, and instead linking to the system framework in XCode. Here are some pointers (the first link is for ios but it should also apply to osx):
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12411208/app-rejected-for-using-libsqlite3-dylib
http://www.ajaxapp.com/2011/08/30/how-to-add-sqlite-framework-into-xcode-4-for-your-ios-app/
The latest one works perfectly here.
make install (invoked in the top level directory, containing BUILDING, ...) doesn't seem to do anything except produce output; no files are installed anywhere.  The program has already been build using make, and seems to work fine.
On Tue, 2014-05-27 at 11:20 -0700, Martin Kleusberg wrote:
> You're using qmake, I suppose? Because we had some difficulties when
> it came to using extended features with qmake we've made the decision
> to move to cmake. We try to keep qmake support but only for a quick
> build; when it comes to a release build or things like make install
> I'd suggest using cmake. I hope this is an option for you :)
I downloaded sqlite-browser using the command:
```
$ git clone https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser.git
```
and invoked make (not cmake or qmake) on sqlitebrowser/Makefile.  The
## sqlitebrowser binary generated seems to run OK.
On Wed, 2014-05-28 at 15:28 -0700, Justin Clift wrote:
> Sounds like we should add build instructions for Linux too.
```
Provided you have Qt and cmake  installed and configured, simply
run
followed by
make
```
When I find a Makefile in a build directory, I assume that the packager
has already run whatever is needed to generate it, and that they have
probably done a better job than I will (at least for a first cut), so in
this cas I didn't run qmake.  If you want sqlitebrowser to be built
using cmake rather than make, the above should read:
```
Provided you have Qt and cmake  installed and configured, simply
run
followed by
```
If you want me to be sure to regenerate the Makefile using cmake, you
## need to say so very explicitly.
(I am large, I contain multitudes.)"
-- Walt Whitman

Thanks very much!
This is more a comment than a bug report, but I noticed this when testing the fix for issue #16.
Suppose you have a BLOB containing multiple null-terminated strings. When you edit the blob, everything is fine as type:Binary, but if you change the type to "Text" in the EditDialog the length of the data remains the same but only the data up to the first null is shown (understandable, but not what the user might expect). Switching back to type:Binary shows all the data again.
However, if you change the data in the type:Text view it is immediately truncated at the first null (the new length shown at the bottom of the EditDialog window), and switching back to type:Binary only shows the truncated data.
I do think it's a valuable facility to be able to edit text within a blob - editing UTF-8 encoded text in hex mode is only fun once :-)
Yes, it seems to be a very difficult area.  Full function UTF8-aware hex/text editors seem very few and far between.
Perhaps it would be reasonable to settle for disabling Text editing for blobs :-(
By the way, I only discovered by accident that the binary edit mode has the text displayed on the right hand side - it's completely hidden when the EditDialog opens at its default size!
Maybe make the default width enough to show the 16 bytes in both hex and text?
@MKleusberg both commits appear to have achieved what was intended - looks good, thanks!
May I make a couple more (final?) comments? (although I understand you may have better things to do than attend to this level of detail)
1. there is no visible representation of a null byte in the text view, and
2."Select all" highlights all the text, but "copy" only copies up to the first null
Seeing where there is a null means I'm less likely to remove it by mistake.
Being able to copy the entire blob value at least gives me the opportunity to take the data for processing elsewhere (and a really nice feature of the EditDialog is that I can get my binary data back into sqlitebrowser by pasting it as hex pairs).
Here's what I see on Windows 8.1:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7688713/3209796/2d42edac-ee8b-11e3-9574-fbe521985263.png)
To my mind, the best solution is, as you suggest, to extend the hex editor widget if possible to allow input on the right side.
By the way, the hex editor doesn't appear to make any attempt to display multi-byte UTF-8 characters ("caf√©" will appear as "caf.."). Another Qt constraint?
Just started using the much-improved v3.1.0 via PortableApps - Thanks!
However, I now find that columns with a declared type of TEXT with values which are UTF-8 strings longer than 1024 bytes now appear as (BLOB), both in the Browse Data tab and in the Execute SQL tab result pane. SQLite returns typeof() as 'text'.
Not sure what the previous PortableApps version was, but it displayed text values as text all the way up to my longest string of about 13K.
Is this a limit that you could consider raising/removing? (browsing/editing BLOB data is a tad less friendly than TEXT data!)

Many thanks for the super quick fix!
The tool of choice to translate pure Qt applications (like sqlitebrowser) is Qt Linguist. As Rene said, the code is mostly ready for it, as it uses tr() to display strings. If possible I would like to stay away from Launchpad, as it is too specific to Ubuntu/Canonical. We had a lot of problems in the past in KDE, with Launchpad translations taking precedence over upstream ones in some cases.
In issue #57 I made translation to Russian.
Thanks!
It is a nice enhancement, but be aware that by itself SQLite does not include an encryption library. One is available from HWCI (http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/see.html), for a fee.
As sqlitebrowser is distributed with source we can not include SEE with sqlitebrowser. You can, however, license the extension and compile your own binary with SEE included (I have done this in the past for the Arca Database Browser, the product from which sqlitebrowser was derived from).

Thanks.

I'm testing the version with sqlcipher with success under osx 10.6. One question: can I add a parameter like e.g. a filename when I start via the command line of Terminal?
Of course we don't enter the password visible on the command line, but things like file-path and name, eventually some options like page-size if it's not the default of 1024 bytes. I asked this to get only the question for a password to any user and in case of a wrong answer they have no access (or just read views, their "own" data etc.

Hi,
I will try my best to explain in detail my build set:
- Miscrosoft visual studio c++ 2013, but I think any version is ok, link download: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=517284
- SQLCipher: I just try to link with 2 differents versions, and it works all fine:
- 1st one is SQLCipher C/C++ DLL for Windows that I requested for a 30 days trial on their main site (https://www.zetetic.net/sqlcipher/trial/)
- 2nd one is a self compilation (mingw32 + code source: https://www.zetetic.net/sqlcipher/open-source), here's a guide link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29196087/step-by-step-guide-to-build-qt-sql-driver-plugin-for-sqlite-db-with-sqlcipher-ex (part 5)
- These variables in CMakeLists.txt must be modified to match your preferences:
```
+ QT5_PATH
+ SQLITE3_PATH (path to foremost folder of SQL Cipher)
+ OPENSSL_PATH
+ LIBSQLITE_NAME (sqlcipher or sqlite3 depends on the name of your .dll file)
+ SQLITE3_INCLUDE_DIRS (sqlite3.h)
+ SQLITE3_LIBS (name of your .dll file)
```
- Then everything left is just open sqlitebrowser MSVC solution then build
I'm sure that I might miss something, so if there anything wrong, just ask here, I will look back at my build and answer, for now that's all I remember.
Cheers,

case: 1. git clone repo.
2. open sqlitebrowser.pro through Qt Creator 3.0.0. (based on  Qt 5.2.0  - 64 but)
3. Celan All -> Run qmake -> Build All
4. thrown error
Resolved by adding major version settings to qhexedit.pro and qcustomplot .pro files.
Major version settings added properly to qhexedit.pro and qcustomplot .pro files.
